Most current policy:     Order no. 680- For closing bars, restaurants, fast food and restaurants  In the order no. 615, dated 9.11.2020, "On the closure of bars, restaurants, fast food and bars", as amended, the following change is made:  1. This order enters into force immediately and takes effect on 24.12.2020. As of Jan. 6, authorities in Albania are maintaining an indefinite 2200-0600 nationwide curfew in efforts to stem the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19). Residents may only leave their homes for essential work and health emergencies during curfew hours. All restaurants, bars, and cafes remain closed except for delivery services. Most nonessential businesses are permitted to open during noncurfew hours. Gatherings are limited to 10 people, and facemasks are mandatory in all indoor and outdoor public spaces.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118002207/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/426036/albania-authorities-to-indefinitely-maintain-covid-19-related-nationwide-2200-0600-curfew-update-17

"Authorities in Albania have extended the nation's existing suspension of flights to and from the UK through at least Feb. 1 in response to a new strain of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) initially discovered in the southeast of England; the suspension was originally slated to expire on Jan. 18. In addition, all passengers who arrive in Albania having the UK as their point of origin must self-isolate for 14 days upon entry. International flights and maritime transport continue to operate in Albania. Moreover, all land borders are open, and no mandatory quarantine requirement is in place except for travelers arriving from the UK."    /web/20210118002158/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/430736/albania-authorities-extend-covid-19-related-suspension-of-flights-to-and-from-uk-until-feb-1-update-18

Direct fights between the UK and Albania are currently suspended    https://web.archive.org/web/20210130220950/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/albania

The Ministry of Health announced that starting December 22, 2020, until January 6, 2021, there will be a mandatory 14-day quarantine (self-isolate) for all travelers who enter Albania by air, land, or sea who initiated their travel from Great Britain.  There is no general requirement for travellers returning to Albania to self-quarantine.  Quarantine will only apply in specific cases when ordered by health authorities, as noted above.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210206165330/https://al.usembassy.gov/updates_covid19/
No policy change

In September, the government launched an employment promotion program, that aims to cover part of reemployment costs of those who lost their jobs during the lockdown. For formal sector employees the government will cover half of the wages (at the legal minimum level) and the full employers’ share of social contributions for the duration of the program (4 or 8 months). Informal sector employees who lost their jobs during the lockdown, will have the full cost of social contributions (employees and employers share) covered for one year if they formalize.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210130223812/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The government has also adopted tax deferral measures allowing all large companies (except banks, telecommunication, public enterprises and other essential businesses) to defer payment of profit tax for the second and third quarter of 2020 in 2021. Tourism, active processing and call centers can defer payments for the rest of 2020 to 2021. Small businesses with turnover below Lk14m will not pay profit tax for the remainder of 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210130223812/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

A:    Vaccination begins in Albania for frontline medical workers and personnel.    The Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine is being used.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118105529/https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/health/albania-carries-out-1st-vaccinations-with-donated-doses/

A:  A total of 549 doctors, nurses, epidemiologists have been vaccinated, who are in the front line of providing services to patients with COVID. (by 21 Jan)  The Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine is being used.    According to the National Vaccination Plan against COVID19, the first to be vaccinated are health personnel on the front line of the fight against COVID-19, followed by those at risk who live or work in nursing homes and other groups of health workers such as and the elderly who have the highest mortality, persons who have concomitant diseases, and who take severe forms of death. People who perform other services critical to society, such as teachers, police or others, will also be vaccinated.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://shendetesia.gov.al/21-janar-vijon-vaksinimi-anticovid-vaksinohen-549-personel-shendetesor/

A:  A total of 662 doctors, nurses, laboratory technicians, epidemiologists have been vaccinated, who are in the first line of service for patients with COVID19. (By 29 Jan)  The Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine is being used.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210130211839/https://shendetesia.gov.al/29-janar-vaksinimi-anticovid-vaksinohen-662-personel-shendetesor/

Andorra is implementing its vaccination campaign using the Pfizer vaccine. The vaccines have been administered to healthcare and social healthcare workers from various fields as well as the residents of the social healthcare homes which have not been recently affected by the virus. The Government has also initiated a campaign to raise awareness and provide information about the vaccine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209112704/https://www.govern.ad/covid19_newsletter/en/

This strategy has been further strengthened using antigen testing. As part of this initiative, the Government has provided three home test kits for every Andorran resident over the age of 6. People are advised to conduct a test, which is done through a nasal swab, before any social gathering.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209112704/https://www.govern.ad/covid19_newsletter/en/

No policy changes.    Article 1. Basic prevention measures  1. The use of masks is mandatory for all people aged 1 to or over. It is recommended from six years old, unless the health situation of the school makes it mandatory.  2. The masks that can be used can be surgical, homemade or hygienic.  3. The use of the mask is mandatory on public roads, in closed spaces for public use and in open spaces, regardless of the need to maintain a minimum safety distance of one and a half meters.    per decree from 20th Nov 2020   https://web.archive.org/web/20210118120509/https://www.bopa.ad/bopa/032138/Pagines/GD20201123_17_36_24.aspx     which has been extended on 13th Jan 2021 with Decree 6/2021. If you are passing through an urban area and/or an outdoor area used by the public:  We recommend maintaining a distance of 4 metres from the person in front and always walking on the right-hand side. It is mandatory wearing a face mask.    If you are in an enclosed area used by the public:   You must maintain a distance of 1.5 metres in enclosed areas; the use of the face mask is mandatory.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209111506/https://visitandorra.com/en/covid-19-in-andorra/faq-what-safety-measures-are-being-applied-in-andorra/
Still no shots in arms, no updates since the previously coded announcement.

The first doses of the SARS-CoV-2 Coronavirus vaccine arrived in Andorra on Tuesday evening. These are 1,000 units of the Pfizer vaccine from Madrid, to which will be added 1,000 more - those corresponding to the second dose of vaccination to be administered - over the next few days.  As stated by the Minister of Health, Joan Martínez Benazet, phase 1 of the vaccination campaign will begin tomorrow (Jan 20, 2021). Thus, the first vaccinated will be users of health centers and health professionals. This first vaccination round will last for two weeks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210126110307/https://www.govern.ad/comunicats/item/12342-arriben-les-primeres-dosis-de-la-vacuna-contra-el-coronavirus

A,C:  The Minister of Health has announced the start of vaccination against COVID-19, which took place this morning in different parts of the country. The vaccination is currently aimed at residents of health centers and health professionals. The ministry believes that the administration of this first consignment will last approximately two weeks. Finally, the minister explained that in addition to the 1,000 doses received yesterday (Jan 19, 2021), 1,000 more will be added this week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210126111139/https://www.govern.ad/comunicats/item/12348-administrades-les-primeres-200-dosis-de-la-vacuna-a-residents-de-centres-sociosanitaris-i-professionals-de-la-salut

A,C:  This Thursday (Jan 21, 2021), a new consignment arrived in the country with 1,000 more vaccines that will be used to administer the second dose to the first thousand people and thus achieve immunity against the SARS-CoV-2 virus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210126112624/https://www.govern.ad/comunicats/item/12350-andorra-s-aprovisiona-de-la-vacuna-contra-la-covid-19-seguint-els-criteris-i-mecanismes-establerts-a-europa

From 18 January, the new CoV self-tests for schoolchildren and teachers will be used in schools - but only to a limited extent due to the postponed return to face-to-face teaching. For the anterio-nasal tests, a simple smear with a swab in the anterior nasal area is sufficient; a result is available after around 15 minutes. In the future, the tests should be on the program once a week on Mondays.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118191154/https://orf.at/stories/3197471/

** School closures, originally planned to end on the 25th, appear to have been extended in a limited form. **    According to the Bundesministerium, schools will continue to operate from January 25, 2021 in location-independent lessons (distance learning). Elementary school, lower secondary level schools are open for supervision and educational support. For AHS upper level, middle and higher schools, vocational schools, the location-independent lessons remain in place. Pupils should still be able to return to the schools in groups or classes on one or more days.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210122141315/https://www.bmbwf.gv.at/Themen/schule/beratung/corona/schulbetrieb20210118.html

"After the semester break, schools in Lower Austria and Vienna will start on February 8, 2021, in all other federal states from February 15, 2021."    "Schools are returning to face-to-face teaching. Primary schools resume regular operations. For secondary levels I and II, face-to-face lessons apply in 2-day shifts. Universities will remain distance learning until further notice. Kindergartens resume normal operations."    Sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20210212143731/https://www.bmbwf.gv.at/Themen/schule/beratung/corona/schulbetrieb20210118.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210212203745/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/

Funerals can take place with a maximum of 50 people.     Demonstrations are allowed.    The minimum distance and the FFP2 obligation must be observed at all events. "COVID-19 virus variant regulation (departure from Tyrol)  The following applies from February 12 to February 21, 2021: People who are leaving the federal state of Tyrol must have proof of a negative PCR or antigen test result, although the test must not be more than 48 hours ago.    "An exception is for    - Children under 10 years,  - averting immediate danger to life, limb and property,  - Organs of the public security service as well as members of rescue organizations and the fire brigade,  - freight transport,  - Transit passengers or the transit through Tyrol without a stopover, which is also present in the case of exclusively essential interruptions,  - for leaving the district of Lienz, the community of Jungholz and the Riss valley in the district of Vomp and Eben am Achensee. (see corresponding regulation )"    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210212203745/https://corona-ampel.gv.at/aktuelle-massnahmen/bundesweite-massnahmen/

From 15 January, all travellers entering Austria will need to register electronically in advance and obtain a so-called pre-travel clearance (PTC). At the border, they will have to show their PTC (either digitally or as a hard copy). In parallel with this registration requirement, the current quarantine obligation remains in force until further notice, “testing oneself free” (“Freitesten”) is possible after 5 days at the earliest. Exceptions to quarantine and registration requirements apply to commuters, transients and persons entering the country for urgent family matters that cannot be postponed.  The only countries exempt from the quarantine obligation, but not from the registration requirement, are Australia, Finland, Greece, Iceland, Japan, New Zealand, Norway, Singapore, South Korea and Vatican.    This is applicable until 31 March 2021, further developments to be observed.    https://archive.fo/7jXrE  https://archive.vn/m4Yeg  https://web.archive.org/web/20210118175604/https://www.bmk.gv.at/service/corona/einreisebestimmungen.html
No change in policy.

** No change in policy. **     According to emergency regulation introduced by the Wirtschaftskammer, if over-indebtedness occurs in the period from March 1, 2020 to March 31, 2021, there is no obligation (but still the possibility) of the debtor to file an application to open insolvency proceedings. In the event of insolvency, there is still an obligation to apply.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210126095617/https://www.wko.at/service/wirtschaftsrecht-gewerberecht/insolvenz-covid-19.html

Austria was to embark on a mass-testing scheme on the 15, 16 and 17 January with the obligation of a compulsory testing requirement in order to re-enter society after the lockdown. Those who received a negative test were to be allowed to leave the house and visit retail shops and hospitality (cafes and restaurants) from 18 January. Those who are not tested would be required to quarantine for another week until 25 January. For all those who were not willing to be tested, the lockdown rules were to apply a week longer. Since the lockdown has been extended until 7 February, the mass testing scheme has been scrapped.    https://archive.vn/y6WbB

** Austria on Wednesday passed a resolution in the National Council to offer coronavirus antigen tests free of charge at pharmacies across the country. The non-binding resolution is expected to become law in the coming days, Austria’s Kurier newspaper reports, after which the “free coronavirus self-tests should be distributed as soon as possible”. **    http://web.archive.org/web/20210126100826/https://www.thelocal.at/20210121/austria-to-make-coronavirus-tests-available-free-at-pharmacies

As part of the extension of the lockdown until 7 February, Austrian Chancellor declared that FFP2 masks are now required in public transport, retail and supermarkets. Previously, cotton masks or scarves were sufficient to satisfy the regulation.    While FFP2 masks are more expensive than standard medical masks, the government has promised that they will be available to Austrians at cost price. People on low incomes would be entitled to the masks for free, a government spokesperson said.    https://archive.vn/uX3BV
No change in policy.

** From 25 January medical-grade FPP2 masks are mandated in shops and on public transport. **    Wearing an FFP2 mask without an exhalation valve (or an equivalent or higher-quality mask) is mandatory for the following areas:     Public transportation  Carpooling, taxis and taxi-like operations as well as at stops, stations and departure halls (also outdoors)  Cable cars and cog railways  Customer areas of commercial establishments as well as of non-body-related service companies (body-related services remain prohibited)  Connecting structures of shopping centers  Markets (indoor and outdoor)  Party traffic by administrative authorities and administrative courts  Gastronomy - if open ( e.g.  when picking up food and in company canteens)  Accommodation establishments - if open (in generally accessible areas such as the lobby or at the reception, does not apply in the room; entry is still only possible for exceptional reasons such as urgent professional purposes)    https://archive.vn/zk0aB  https://archive.vn/TAMfL

Schools are open with sanitation requirements- e.g. in some schools there is both online and in person teaching to reduce contact  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115144807if_/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/faq/#id_6  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115151046/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/belgian-high-schoolers-demand-to-get-back-inperson-learning-students-school-students-learning-coronavirus-pandemic-b1786453.html  All pupils can go to school but social distancing measures are in place https://web.archive.org/web/20210115144807/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/faq/ The school follows a  plan with measures against corona . This way your child stays safe. The plan has 4 phases: green, yellow, orange and red. Each phase has different measures. The measures differ per educational level. All primary and secondary schools will start in code orange from 16 November. Part-time art education and adult education will start in code red from 16 November. Are there more infections in your municipality? Then there may be an orange or red phase in your school. Your municipality and your school will give you more information. Staff, students and parents also adhere to the precautions. The school can take more measures if it deems it necessary. You will then receive more information. If a person becomes infected, the CLB follows a step-by-step plan. https://web.archive.org/web/20210115145823/https://onderwijs.vlaanderen.be/nl/node/9335#e9444d2c-8021-49da-8ddd-29c415ca07d0

No policy changes.    You may travel to Belgium when:  You are a resident of the European Union, Schengen Area or the United Kingdom.  You are travelling from a country that has been included in the list of the FPS Foreign Affairs.    All other countries are banned from travelling to Belgium. You may only travel from these countries to Belgium for an essential reason. A list of the essential reasons can be found in the frequently asked questions.  https://archive.vn/8JWx9    Note that:  From Monday 25 January, all travellers travelling to Belgium from the UK, South Africa and South America will be required to be quarantined for 10 days with a PCR test on day 1 and day 7.  From 27 January, international traffic will be further restricted. During the period of the ban, only essential travel is permitted.  Also, every non-resident travelling to Belgium will need to provide a negative test prior to departure, and will be tested again on arrival in Belgium. This can be done with a PCR test or a rapid antigen test.  https://archive.vn/3XQmF

Non-essential trips in and out of Belgium are prohibited from Wednesday 27 January to Monday 1 March 2021. The travel ban will be monitored for road, air, sea and rail traffic.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210202015844/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/news/occ-2201/

No policy changes. Comprehensive contact tracing in place.    Process explained as follows:    Do you test positive?  •	Stay in isolation for at least 7 days.  •	The persons living in your house must be in quarantine.  •	Try to make a list of the people you have had contact with in the past days. Think about the people you met from two days before you had symptoms (e.g. your colleagues, a friend you went for a walk with, your own family members, the postman, etc.).  •	Your list of contacts should preferably include their name, telephone number, address, date of birth and e-mail address.  A government employee will call you from the number 02/214.19.19. It is important that you answer the employee’s questions as fully as possible:  •	He or she will ask you about the list of contacts you drew up.  •	You should give some extra information about yourself in order to be able to assess the situation as concretely as possible: your date of birth, general state of health, profession, contact with people at risk, etc.  This data will be treated confidentially. Thanks to your contribution, your contacts can be notified in good time and they can follow up any symptoms well.    https://archive.vn/IgGHs

No change found    If you came into contact with someone who has the coronavirus, you will receive a phone call or a text message from contact tracing.  Stay at home. Go into quarantine for 7 days. The quarantine period starts when you last had contact with the person who has coronavirus. Get tested seven days after your encounter with a high-risk contact.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210115164828/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/testing/

***Recoded from 3T to 3G, list of places throughout country where face mask is mandatory is exhaustive enough to be a general requirement warranting a 3G coding     No policy changes.    Since Monday 26 October 2020, wearing a face mask is mandatory in Brussels throughout the Brussels-Capital Region (from 12 years). The face mask has to cover the mouth and nose.  https://archive.vn/P0wEi    In the rest of the country, masks are mandatory in a variety of specific places:    Everyone, with the exception of children up to the age of 12, is obliged to cover their mouth and nose with a face mask or any other fabric alternative in all situations where it is impossible to ensure compliance with the rules of social distancing. This last obligation does not apply to:  •	people living under the same roof;  •	children mixing up to the age of 12;  •	people meeting each who have close contact on a regular basis;  •	counsellors and their clients (people in need of counselling).  In addition, wearing a face mask is compulsory in a number of places, regardless of the number of people present there:  •	On public transport from entering the airport, the station, on the platform or a bus, (pre-)metro, tram, train stop or any other means of transport organised by a public authority. Public transport drivers are not required to cover their nose and mouth, insofar as the driver is well-isolated in a cabin on the one hand, and a poster and/or sticker indicates to users the reason why the driver is not wearing a mask on the other;  •	For supervisors of camps, training sessions and activities that are allowed;  •	The establishments and places where catering activities are permitted, both for customers and staff, unless whilst eating, drinking or sitting at a table;  •	In shops and shopping centres;  •	In shopping streets, at markets and in any private or public are with significant footfall, which is determined by the competent local authority and demarcated by a notice specifying the times at which the obligation applies;  •	In conference rooms, auditoriums and places of worship & reflection;  •	In libraries, game and multimedia libraries;  •	in museums;  •	In places of worship and buildings intended for the public practice of non-denominational moral services;  •	When moving around in public and non-public parts of courthouses and courtrooms and, in other cases, in accordance with the guidelines laid down by the Chairman.  When it is not possible to wear a face mask or any fabric alternative due to medical reasons, a face shield can be worn.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210123121642if_/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/faq/#id_7

Attended classes (including internships, internships, outsourced classes, exams, dual system of education, etc.) in schools and personal development support centers are suspended.    From 04.02.2021 to 17.03.2021 an exception is allowed with regard to the present classes for students from fifth to twelfth grade in compliance with the following schedule:    4.02.2021 to 17.02.2021 - students from 7th, 8th and 12th grade are trained in person    18.02.2021 to 2.03.2021 - students from 5th, 10th and 11th grade are trained in person    04.03.2021 to 17.03.2021 - students from 6th, 9th and 12th grade are trained in person    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209041048/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

As of 9 February, attended classes (including internships, internships, outsourced classes, exams, dual system of education, etc.) in schools and personal development support centers are suspended.     An exception is allowed for students from first to fourth grade and the individual attendance visits to the centers for support of personal development.     Other exceptions are allowed for equivalence exams for student transfer, examinations for determining the annual grade for a student in an independent form of education, examinations for determining the annual grade for a part-time student, state examinations for acquiring a degree of professional qualification in theory and practice of the profession, regional and municipal rounds of Olympiads and competitions, when they cannot be held remotely in an electronic environment.    Visits to kindergartens and nurseries have resumed.     The present learning process in the higher schools is terminated, with the exception of conducting practical trainings and practical exams for students, postgraduates and doctoral students, semester exams which include a practical part and cannot be conducted in an electronic environment, state exams, and diploma theses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209041048/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

All cultural and entertainment events are suspended.     Visits to theaters, cinemas, museums, and galleries are allowed, but are restricted to 30% of the total capacity. As of 9 February, the temporary ban for the entry into the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria of remains in effect.    The ban does not apply to Bulgarian citizens, citizens of Member States of the European Union (EU), Schengen Parties (including the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the Vatican City State) and their family members (including persons in actual residence with them); citizens of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, the Union of Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, the Republic of Rwanda, the Republic of Korea, the Kingdom of Thailand, the Republic of Tunisia, the Oriental Republic of Uruguay, the United Arab Emirates, Ukraine, the Republic of Northern Macedonia The Republic of Albania, Kosovo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, the Republic of Moldova, Israel, the State of Kuwait, the Republic of Belarus and the Republic of Turkey; persons with permanent status, long-term or long-term residence on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria and the members of their families; persons holding a Bulgarian long-stay visa type "D", as well as persons holding a residence permit in a Member State of the European Union or a Schengen country (including the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the City State Vatican) and members of their families.    All persons who are allowed to enter the country are admitted to the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria upon submission of a document showing a negative result from a polymerase chain reaction test conducted up to 72 hours before entry to prove COVID-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209041048/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

As of 9 February, the unified information portal remains the official source of information on measures to combat the spread of COVID-19 in Bulgaria (https://coronavirus.bg). The portal provides statistics, news, press briefings, video materials, information about vaccines, and answers to frequently asked questions.     An official chatbot of the Council of Ministers of the Republic of Bulgaria is available, which provides real-time official information and news about COVID-19 through Viber.     The ViruSafe mobile app is available, which gives users the ability to track their symptoms and health status daily. This information gives the Ministry of Health a good overview of the spread of the pandemic. As of 9 February, testing procedures depend on whether the individual is a first- or second-line contact person, suffers from a chronic illness, falls into the risk category of people over 60, is a medical professional, and has symptoms.     Testing for coronavirus is performed at the discretion of the regional health inspectorate, the medical institution where the patient is hospitalized or the relevant medical person in the designated places for examination and diagnosis (based on symptoms) or with a referral from a general practitioner.    Optional testing can be done in a private laboratory.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209055248/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/az-sum/litse-simptomi

According to the Order ? RD-01-547/30.09.202 of the Minister of Health, all close contacts of a confirmed case of COVID-19 are subject to a 10-day quarantine, as of their last contact with the infected person. Also, the monitoring of the health condition of each contact person is performed by the general practitioner or the respective regional health inspection. A:    The immunization of the second and third phases of the National Vaccination Plan against COVID-19 will be carried out in parallel. The members of the Central Election Commission, the district and section commissions, with which the third phase of the plan has started, will be offered the Pfizer / BioNTech vaccine. This ensures that the immunization is completed with two doses of the vaccine, so that those involved in the election can be maximally protected from the virus by election day. The overlap of the phases allows Bulgarian journalists, cameramen and photojournalists to be immunized in the third phase of the Plan.     The third phase will continue with employees of Kozloduy Nuclear Power Plant, water supply and sewage companies employed in the transport and communications sectors, and police officers working on the first line.    Vaccination of vulnerable groups remains a top priority for the Ministry of Health. Therefore, the end of the third phase of the National Vaccination Plan will be covered by the beginning of the fourth. In this phase, those covered by immunization will be "Elderly people over 65 years of age and those with concomitant chronic diseases, due to the more severe course of the disease and the higher risk of complications and death, including immunocompromised or persons with secondary immune deficiencies."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209065902/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1292

A:    More than 5,000 teachers and support staff in Sofia have expressed a desire to be immunized against COVID-19. This is a little over 20% of the pedagogical and non-pedagogical staff in the kindergartens and schools in the municipality of Sofia. Vaccination began on February 1, and more than 160 people were immunized in just one day.     The Sofia Regional Health Inspectorate has so far received about 30,000 doses of Pfizer / BioNTech and Moderna vaccines, informed the director of SRHI, Dr. Dancho Penchev. He explained that the first phase of the National Vaccination Plan is coming to an end in the capital, which includes the medical staff of outpatient and inpatient care facilities, medical specialists in health care, dentists, pharmacists, assistant pharmacists and other support staff.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209070608/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1263

All delivered quantities of AstraZeneca vaccine to be used for the first dose, decided today at its regular meeting the Council of the National Vaccination Headquarters. In this way, larger groups of the population will be covered and the immunization process will be accelerated.    The staff will recommend that medical professionals administer the second dose of the vaccine ten weeks after the first, according to the possibilities provided by the summary of product characteristics.    The members of the vaccination headquarters expressed the opinion that the Oxford vaccine can be used for vaccination of all Bulgarian citizens aged 18 and over.    It became clear at the meeting that the delivery of the Pfizer / BioNTech vaccine was postponed due to bad weather conditions, and is expected to arrive in Bulgaria in the middle of the week.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209065902/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1292

A:    Vaccines for all those wishing to participate in the election process are provided, Angelov was adamant. The Ministry of Health has sent a letter to the CEC requesting a list of names and contact details of the people to be immunized. The aim is to create an organization that ensures the safe conduct of parliamentary elections.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210211230615/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/1297

Bosnia and Herzegovina has still not started vaccination. Since the country is completely dependent on the COVAX system, the first vaccinations are not expected until mid-February. Between 5,000 and 10,000 doses are expected in the first delivery. So far, vaccinations are only available for 20% of the population. Direct purchases of Pfizer, Sputnik V and Sinopharm vaccinations are expected to vaccinate another 20% of the population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210131010146/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html

No new income support announced. Also, Prime Minister Roman Golovchenko said that the government did not see a slowdown in economic activity in Belarus amidst the second wave of COVID-19 and the social commitments of the state were not only fulfilled, but also over-fulfilled as the average salary reached Br1,300.     “The 8.9% increase in real household income is another testimony to the efficient economic performance,”    “Despite the difficult situation our economy is performing quite well, much better than the economies of many of our neighbors, including the economically stronger ones. According to preliminary estimates, our gross domestic product this year will be at least as big as 99% of last year's. This is the main economic outcome. It is very encouraging that the manufacturing industry has bounced back in recent months,”    “Even when the whole world is struggling through the coronavirus second wave, we do not see a slowdown in economic activity in our country so far,”    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228095057/https://eng.belta.by/economics/view/pm-no-economic-slowdown-in-belarus-amidst-coronavirus-second-wave-136198-2020/    Considering the official stand of the Belarus' government regarding Covid-19, new financial/economic/fiscal measures seem unlikely within the upcoming months at least.

Recoded from 1G to 2G, as there is still a nationwide ban on in-person higher education in place, even if some exceptions to the remote learning rule are allowed in practice (e.g. medical dissections).     Original coding note:     Compulsory schools: Face-to-face teaching is permitted. Schools must implement precautionary measures.    Upper secondary schools (e.g. baccalaureate and vocational schools): Classroom teaching is permitted.     Schools must implement precautionary measures. Everyone on site must also wear a mask. There is no restriction on group size for sports tuition and this may also be held in sports halls. The requirements concerning physical distancing and/or the wearing of masks must be observed.    Tertiary level (e.g. universities and other higher education institutions): Face-to-face teaching is permitted only if the students absolutely need to be on site (e.g. instruction on operating a particular machine, dissection during medical studies) and if the teaching forms an essential part of the course of study. Otherwise, a switch to remote learning is required. Examinations linked to study courses or higher vocational training and the examinations necessary for obtaining an official certificate may be held on site provided that the precautionary measures are observed..    https://web.archive.org/web/20210124111124/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html#850493620

In addition to national ban on in-person higher education, some canons have taken the step to close specific school levels in addition. [***coded as 2G to reflect the national policy on universities; however, not coded as a 3T as in no location are ALL levels of schools closed. Localized measures only address some levels of schools, not meeting the threshold for a 3T]     "However, the canton of Aargau decided on Wednesday to close its secondary schools and professional schools and continue classes via online learning from next Monday until the end of February. One aim is to reduce the number of students on public transport.    On Thursday, the canton of Solothurn decided to close its secondary schools and professional schools and continue classes via online learning from next Monday until at least 26 February 2021. It is also extending mask wearing to primary school children from the 5th year."    https://archive.vn/PwWqY#selection-521.0-525.271

"Tertiary level (e.g. universities and other higher education institutions): Face-to-face teaching is permitted only if the students absolutely need to be on site (e.g. instruction on operating a particular machine, dissection during medical studies) and if the teaching forms an essential part of the course of study. Otherwise, a switch to remote learning is required. Examinations linked to study courses or higher vocational training and the examinations necessary for obtaining an official certificate may be held on site provided that the precautionary measures are observed."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210205074434/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

Restaurants, cultural venues, and sports and leisure facilities are to remain closed until the end of February.     It is also introducing new measures to drastically reduce contact between people. From Monday, 18 January, there will be a requirement to work from home, shops selling non-essential goods will be closed, stricter rules will apply to private events and gatherings, and measures to protect those at especially high risk will be strengthened in the workplace.    https://archive.vn/Sft4a#selection-3399.0-3405.1    Museums, cinemas, casinos, botanical gardens and zoos, and also other cultural and recreational facilities, are closed. In libraries and archives, only the reading rooms are closed; it is still possible to borrow books.    Discotheques and dance venues are closed. Dance events may not be held.    Sports and wellness facilities are closed. This includes fitness centres, artificial ice rinks and swimming pools. The following remain open: ski areas, equestrian sports facilities and facilities in hotels which are only accessible to hotel guests.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210124111124/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html#accordion1611333018502

ON BUSINESS CLOSURE:   This policy requires "Closure of shops selling non-essential goods. In addition, the Federal Council is introducing stricter national measures with effect from Monday 18 January. All shops and markets other than those selling essential everyday goods are to close. It will still be possible to collect ordered goods."     However, "Service providers such as banks, hair salons, post offices and mobile phone stores are allowed to stay open but are subject to a curfew of 7pm and will have to close on Sunday. However, this curfew will no longer apply to kiosks and petrol station shops. Ski resorts are able to stay open provided they comply with protection measures."     ON WORK FROM HOME:   "From Monday, 18 January, there will be a requirement to work from home", however, a closer inspection of policy reveals that it is only mandatory that "Employers will be required to enable all staff to work from home where it is feasible and practicable for them to do so based on the type of activity. Employers will not be required to assume expenses incurred by employees for electricity or rent etc. as this is a temporary measure."     While the policy text seems to allow some exceptions to the work from home, other analyses of this policy refer to it as a mandatory work from home requirement for non-essential workers.    ON CODING:   For now, this policy is coded as a 2G rather than 3G since employees in certain sectors still are able to go to work or choose not to work from home even when given the option. Furthermore, the consideration of ski resorts, hair salons, etc. as 'essential' fails to meet the threshold for 3G, which requires closure of "all-but-essential workplaces" like grocery stores.       SOURCES:   https://archive.vn/Sft4a#selection-3399.0-3405.1    https://web.archive.org/web/20210203163553/https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/business/switzerland-returns-to-lockdown-amid-concerns-over-more-contagious-virus-strain/46283172    https://web.archive.org/web/20210203163944/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/429306/switzerland-authorities-tighten-extend-domestic-covid-19-related-restrictions-from-jan-18-update-24

Second vaccine - Moderna - approved for use on January 12.     B;C     Targeted groups amended to explicitly identify care home/retirement home residents and staff : "The following people are being given access to vaccinations first:    People age 75 and over  People with chronic diseases of the highest risk, regardless of their age  People who live in a retirement or care home. Staff who are in contact with residents of retirement and care homes also have the option of being vaccinated at the same time."     However, still coded as two groups rather than three as "key workers" are not categorically being vaccinated; rather, only some care/retirement home staff has the option of vaccination.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210124122931/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html

Recoded from 1G to 2G as official government policy allows for both B & C to access vaccine nationally, despite lags or variation in localized vaccine rollout. Not coded as 3G as "key workers" are not able to categorically access the vaccine; rather only a limited portion of care/retirement home workers have the option of vaccination.     B;C , Moderna & Pfizer    Original coding note:     Note that the federal policy is to give access first to A, B and C:    The following people are being given access to vaccinations first:  ?	People age 75 and over  ?	People with chronic diseases of the highest risk, regardless of their age  ?	People who live in a retirement or care home. Staff who are in contact with residents of retirement and care homes also have the option of being vaccinated at the same time.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124122931/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html    However, the status is that only elderly people are indeed getting shots in arms in all cantons. In some cantons B and C are vaccinated. In Zurich, A and C. In others, only C (detailed sources below). Based on the coding guidance that Geographic coverage needs to be national before this is coded, as we code the lowest common value if there is geographic variation, changing to 1G.  Approved vaccines: Pfizer/BioNTec, Moderna. Undergoing approval process: AstraZeneca    https://web.archive.org/web/20210110150607/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html    Clinically vulnerable people under 75 now also being vaccinated as well, e.g. in Zug:  https://archive.vn/v7s4P  and Baselland:  https://archive.vn/KPry4    But the roll out varies across cantons, e.g. in Basel-city only the elderly over 75 are being invited to get vaccinated.  https://archive.vn/WVWiv  https://archive.vn/hJDAb    Similarly, in Bern, where only people over 75 years old are being vaccinated for now.  https://archive.vn/rRwCL#selection-1591.0-1595.92    In Zurich, residents and staff in elderly care home have started to receive vaccines.   https://archive.vn/cZiRN  In Tessin, elderly care home residents and staff, as well as the over 85-year-olds can book vaccinations.  https://archive.vn/T29oA    Note there are reports of a slow roll out of the vaccine program.  https://archive.vn/ukR7N

No policy changes.    B;C , Moderna & Pfizer    The following people are being given access to vaccinations first:    People age 75 and over  People with chronic diseases of the highest risk, regardless of their age  People who live in a retirement or care home. Staff who are in contact with residents of retirement and care homes also have the option of being vaccinated at the same time.  If you are in the group of people with chronic diseases of the highest risk, the doctor treating you will urgently recommend you to have the vaccination as soon as possible.    After that come:    People aged between 65 and 74  People under 65 and people with chronic diseases who have not yet been vaccinated  Following people at especially high risk (vulnerable people), the vaccination will also be offered to the following target groups in the corresponding order.    Target group 2: Healthcare professionals with patient contact/carers for people at especially high risk  Target group 3: Close contacts (household members or relatives providing care) of people at especially high risk  Target group 4: People in communal facilities with an increased risk of infection and outbreaks (for example homes for the handicapped).  It has become apparent that these priorities are being put into practice differently from canton to canton. In particular there are differences in the vaccination of healthcare professionals. For this reason the Federal Vaccination Commission (EKIF/CFV) and the FOPH have drawn up guidelines specifying which groups of healthcare professionals may possibly be vaccinated at the same time as especially vulnerable people (target group 1). Given that volumes of vaccine are currently limited, the goal is to assure the provision of healthcare in areas that are particularly affected while making sufficient vaccine available for especially vulnerable people at the highest risk.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210205081724/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html

No change in policy.    According to the Quarantine (Determination of Measures to Prevent the Spread of COVID-19) Decree (No. 6) of 2021:    (i) Private and public schools of primary education shall operate through online education up  to 07 February 2021 and with physical attendance as of 08 February 2021;    (ii) Private and public schools of secondary education shall operate through online education.  As of 08 February 2021, third class of lyceums and technical schools, including the evening  schools and the respective class of the private schools of secondary education shall operate  with physical attendance. The other classes shall operate through online education,    (iii) Private and public nurseries and kindergartens, including pre-primary schools, shall  operate with physical attendance,    (iv) Special schools and the Special Units of public schools shall operate with physical  attendance,    (v) public and private Higher and Tertiary Education Institutions shall operate through online  education    https://web.archive.org/web/20210204164311/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/28012021_DecreeEN.pdf

Private service businesses (e.g., law firms, accounting firms, architectural firms,  insurance companies, service companies, etc.), with the exception of the essential  services set out in the Decree, will work remotely.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210126000202if_/https://publications.gov.cy/assets/user/publications/2021/2021_991/HTML/

From 5am on 10 January, until at least midnight on 31 January, all outings from your place of residence require permission granted either by sending an SMS to “8998” from a Cypriot mobile number, or by completing and carrying a written form if you do not have a Cypriot phone number (or are over 65 and prefer this method). You are also required to carry official identification at all times.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201214091800/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/cyprus/coronavirus

Until at least January 31, a strict island-wide curfew is in effect from 09:00pm to 05:00am with the exceptions of emergency medical reasons and employees with a letter from their employer.     Approval by sending an SMS to 8998 is required to leave one’s residence until at least January 31 (people over 65 can use a printed form). Each resident is permitted two permissions a day. Exceptions are made for dog-walking, taking children to school, and employment.   no changes in policy: https://web.archive.org/web/20210125235223/https://cy.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/?_ga=2.25614906.681852430.1611618647-385059307.1606168314

No change in policy.    Cyprus has implemented an economic support package that is estimated to amount to €899 million (4.5 percent of GDP) in 2020 for the health sector, households and businesses. The package includes: (i) a €100 million support for the health sector to combat the pandemic; (ii) income support for households including leave allowance for parents and those with health issues; (iii) wage subsidy for affected businesses to maintain jobs, grants to small businesses and self-employed, support for the tourism sector, a two-month deferral of VAT payments, and a temporary VAT cut to stimulate tourism/hospitality sector, and (iv) three-month suspension of a scheduled increase in the contribution to the General Healthcare System and interest subsidy for new business and housing loans for four years, which benefit both businesses and households. This package also includes guarantees on or financing of credit facilities up to €1.7 billion through participation in the Pan-European Guarantee Fund, increased state guarantees to expand existing European Investment Bank (EIB)-supported loans to SMEs, and increased government borrowing from EIB to expand existing funding scheme for SMEs. In face of the second wave, Cyprus has extended some of the support measures until March 2021 in a more targeted manner, including support for crisis-affected businesses and extension of unemployment benefits.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210204173927/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

People coming from the countries with very high risk will have to undergo a PCR test for coronavirus before they travel to the Czech Republic and go to quarantine after their arrival. If they undergo another test five or more days afterwards and it is negative again, they will be allowed to end their quarantine, but they will still have to wear an at least FFP2 respirator for five more days.  People from orange countries, with a medium risk, will have to undergo an antigen test not more than 48 hours before their arrival. Until now, this was mandatory only for long-term foreign workers but not for cross-border commuters.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206133544/https://www.expats.cz/czech-news/article/czech-republic-changes-covid-testing-rules-for-arrivals-as-of-friday

A, C  In connection with the launching of the vaccination campaign, the Ministry of Health received permission from the government to issue two extraordinary measures relating to vaccination against COVID-19, coming into effect 14 January. The first allows vaccination against COVID-19 to be carried out on all clients of domestic health insurance companies who express an interest, in line with the vaccination strategy. The second orders vaccination sites to input into a special module of the Infectious Disease Information System without delay all necessary information on the distribution and movement of vaccines so as to ensure uniform and accurate records.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210116172650/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/government-acquaints-itself-with-vaccination-strategy-for-the-czech-republic--vaccination-sites-must-start-reporting-on-vaccine-consumption-186055/

On 19 January, the German Chancellor Angela Merkel announced that all existing measures to contain the corona pandemic continue to apply and are temporarily extended until 14 February 2021.   This means that schools and daycare facilities remain closed or compulsory attendance is suspended. Emergency care will continue to be provided and distance learning will be offered; special arrangements may be made for final-year classes.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210129124516/https://www.deutschland.de/en/news/german-federal-government-informs-about-the-corona-crisis

Decision previously made on 13 Dec 2020 is extended until 14 Feb 2021.  “According to this decision, schools will, as a rule, remain closed or children will continue not to be required to attend classes at school. The same approach will be taken for daycare centres.”  Source: https://archive.fo/Rh2k1

On 19 January, the German Chancellor Angela Merkel announced that all existing measures to contain the corona pandemic continue to apply and are temporarily extended until 14 February 2021.   All shops must close. Only supermarkets and shops for everyday basic needs may remain open. Cafés, restaurants and bars remain closed but may offer take away or delivery services. Employers must allow employees to work in a home office whenever the activities permit, as long as there are no compelling operational reasons to the contrary.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129124516/https://www.deutschland.de/en/news/german-federal-government-informs-about-the-corona-crisis

"The Minister of Labour and Social Affairs will issue a regulation, initially limited until 15 March, according to which employers must allow their employees to work from home wherever possible, provided that their work permits this."  Source: https://archive.fo/Rh2k1

Curfew between 8pm/9pm/10pm (depending on state) and 5am remains in place in Baden-Württemberg, Bayern, Sachsen, Bradenburg, and Thüringen, during which leaving the house is only allowed under very limited circumstances (e.g. medical emergencies). Between 5am and 8pm/9pm/10pm, there are more exceptions, including going to the supermarket, going to work (provided it is required and allowed under other restrictions), and exercise. In Berlin, you can only leave the house with "valid reasons" (effectively exceptions).    Other states have mostly adopted the federal guidelines limiting movement to within 15km around one's home whenever incidence over the past 7 days is above 200 infections/100000 residents. Mecklenburg-Vorpommern,       At least Bremen, Niedersachsen and Hamburg seem to have no such restrictions, making 2T the best fit.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210130185647/https://www.focus.de/gesundheit/coronavirus/corona-regeln-naechtliche-ausgangssperre-in-welchen-bundeslaendern-sie-immer-noch-gilt_id_12858482.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210130191559/https://www.pnn.de/brandenburg/lockdown-bis-zum-31-januar-2021-das-ist-in-potsdam-und-brandenburg-erlaubt/26739656.html

No nationwide curfew in place, but some individual federal states have implemented curfews.  - Bayern: "Accordingly, all existing measures such as the contact restrictions, the night-time curfew as well as the 15-km radius for so-called corona hotspots will continue to apply until mid-February." (http://web.archive.org/web/20210205170659if_/https://www.br.de/nachrichten/deutschland-welt/coronavirus-in-bavaria-assistance-in-english,RtO8eS2)  - Saxony  - Hessen  - Baden-Württemberg  - Berlin  - Brandenburg  - Thuringia  Source: https://archive.fo/jQteO

Generally recommended for everyone to stay at home.  Most states are eventually relaxing night-time curfew to cities with higher-incidence (e.g. Bavaria: "As of next Monday, February 15, the night curfew will be loosened: It will then only apply in cities and districts with a 7-day incidence above 100 and will then be in effect between 10 pm and 5 am. Where the incidence has been below 100 for seven days, a night curfew will no longer apply.")  "In Länder or districts which still cannot bring their incidence below 50 due to their high 7-day incidence, the Länder or districts will maintain or expand further extensive local or regional measures in accordance with the Protection against Infection Act (Infektionsschutzgesetz) in order to rapidly reduce the number of infections."     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210212102635/https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/656632/1853278/d9e762ee06ca3822ebd3d8bc78953cd0/2021-02-10-mpk-beschluss-corona-en-data.pdf?download=1  http://web.archive.org/web/20210212103651/https://www.br.de/nachrichten/deutschland-welt/coronavirus-in-bavaria-assistance-in-english,RtO8eS2

Testing is only required for symptomatic people who fall under certain risk groups, or when recommended by the primary doctor, asymptomatic people in close contact with someone who has tested positive.  "PCR test should be performed  •	if the patient has severe respiratory symptoms such as bronchitis or pneumonia, shortness of breath or fever,  •	if the patient suffers from a disorder of the sense of smell and taste,  •	if the patient has had contact with a confirmed COVID-19 case,  •	if symptoms worsen.  A test can also be performed for symptoms such as a slight cough.  It is tested for mild respiratory symptoms, in particular (but not exclusively):  •	who belongs to a risk group,  •	who works in nursing, a doctor's office or hospital,  •	Anyone who was exposed, i.e. , for example, was with over 10 people in a closed and poorly ventilated room,  •	Anyone who has had contact with a person with unexplained acute illnesses (e.g. fever) and is in a district with an increased 7-day incidence (> 35 / 100,000 inhabitants),  •	who has or will have close contact with many people or with high-risk patients."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210205062130/https://www.rki.de/DE/Content/InfAZ/N/Neuartiges_Coronavirus/Teststrategie/Nat-Teststrat.html

Contact tracing app in place but the government noted that the high number of infections has made contact tracing impossible as coded on 5 Jan 2021.  Currently no new information as to whether contact tracing is more effective now.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210205172822/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/corona-warn-app/corona-warn-app-englisch

Germany has managed to reduce the number of new infections per 100,000 inhabitants over a 7 day period to below 80 nationwide. For some Länder, an incidence of less than 50 is already within sight, although it has not yet been reached.  For contact tracing to be more effective, an acceptable infection rate is 50 cases per 100,000 residents in a 7-day period.  Since this is currently not yet achieved, I have still coded it as 1.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210106175200/https://www.dw.com/en/coronavirus-germany-extends-covid-lockdown-until-january-31/a-56134498  http://web.archive.org/web/20210212102635/https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/656632/1853278/d9e762ee06ca3822ebd3d8bc78953cd0/2021-02-10-mpk-beschluss-corona-en-data.pdf?download=1

On 19 January, the German Chancellor Angela Merkel announced that all existing measures to contain the corona pandemic continue to apply and are temporarily extended until 14 February 2021.   Face masks are mandatory in all places with public circulation. Medical masks (OP masks) or FFP2 masks (or KN95 or N95 masks) are to be worn in public transport and when shopping, according to the decision of the federal and state governments on 19 January.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129124516/https://www.deutschland.de/en/news/german-federal-government-informs-about-the-corona-crisis    ***Recoded from 3G to 2G. While the change impacts the type of mask to be worn, it doesn't change the fact that they are only required in some public spaces, including shops and public transport.

"We have extended the obligation to wear medical masks, i.e. surgical masks or FFP2 or KN95/N95 masks, in order to have a greater protective impact. This applies to public transport and shops, where wearing such masks is mandatory. In general, the use of medical masks is also advised in situations where there is closer or prolonged contact with other people."    Source: https://archive.fo/Rh2k1

"There is therefore an obligation to wear medical masks when using public transport and in shops. In general, the use of medical masks is recommended indoors."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210212102635/https://www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/656632/1853278/d9e762ee06ca3822ebd3d8bc78953cd0/2021-02-10-mpk-beschluss-corona-en-data.pdf?download=1

A, C (both BioNTech/Pfizer and Moderna)  Currently, only people in Group 1 can be vaccinated:  •	Over 80 year olds  •	People who are treated, cared for or cared for in inpatient facilities for older people or people in need of care, or who work,  •	Nursing staff in outpatient care services  •	Employees in medical facilities with a high exposure risk such as intensive care units, emergency rooms, rescue services, as service providers of specialized outpatient palliative care, corona vaccination centers and in areas with infection-related activities  •	Employees in medical facilities who treat, care for or care for people at high risk (especially hemato-oncology and transplant medicine.)    *AstraZeneca vaccine is approved in Germany and EU, but only used for people under 65 y/o – hence currently not used since only priority group 1 is being vaccinated    Source: https://archive.fo/dpmeE

A, C (both BioNTech/Pfizer and Moderna)  Currently, only people in Group 1 can be vaccinated:  •	Over 80 year olds  •	People who are treated, cared for or cared for in inpatient facilities for older people or people in need of care, or who work,  •	Nursing staff in outpatient care services  •	Employees in medical facilities with a high exposure risk such as intensive care units, emergency rooms, rescue services, as service providers of specialized outpatient palliative care, corona vaccination centers and in areas with infection-related activities  •	Employees in medical facilities who treat, care for or care for people at high risk (especially hemato-oncology and transplant medicine.) The Health minister said he does not expect a large-scale reopening of society at the beginning of next month (February). The current restrictions include the closure of schools, universities.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130120629/https://www.thelocal.dk/20210127/dont-expect-denmark-to-reopen-at-start-of-february-minister

Until 28 Feburary, there are remote and online classes for pupils and students where possible (0-4th classes are exempt - As of 8 February the youngest pupils are returning to school. This includes pupils in primary schools from 0 – 4th grade. This re-opening also applies to after-school care facilities.)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210206002505/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/national-measures/covid-19-lockdown

The Health minister said he does not expect a large-scale reopening of society at the beginning of next month (February). The current restrictions include non-essential stores as well as requiring most people to work from home where possible.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130120629/https://www.thelocal.dk/20210127/dont-expect-denmark-to-reopen-at-start-of-february-minister

Citizens are still encouraged to work from home. Durable goods stores, such as DIY stores and interior design shops, must continue to stay closed, as must shopping centres, department stores, shopping arcades and bazaars. The same applies to liberal professions who are not able to maintain the distance required to prevent infections, such as hairdressers, massage therapists, tattooists and driving schools.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210206002505/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/national-measures/covid-19-lockdown

Lockdown extended until Feb 7, includes provisions on cancelling public events    Extension: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130124658/https://www.thelocal.dk/20210113/denmark-expected-to-extend-coronavirus-lockdown-until-february-7th  Guidance on events and gatherings: https://archive.vn/APynh

Events or other activities with more than 5 people gathered simultaneously at the same location are banned. This ban applies to both indoor and outdoor gatherings, and it applies to both public and private events etc.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210206003740/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/national-measures/events-and-gatherings     The ban on gatherings of more than five people does not apply to religious ceremonies, including baptism and marriage, performed in the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Denmark and other religious communities at premises usually at the disposal of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Denmark or another religious community, whereas the ban on gatherings of more than 500 people simultaneously still applies.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210206004058/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/national-measures/religious-ceremonies-etc

To prevent the spreading of the British and South African mutations of COVID-19, the Danish government has imposed a flight ban on transportation of passengers from the entire world who are unable to present a negative COVID-19 test.  The ban will allow passenger flights only under the condition, that all passengers onboard the airplane have been tested negative for COVID-19 within 24 hours of boarding the plane. Children under the age of 12 will be excluded from the test requirement  http://web.archive.org/web/20210115173415/https://coronasmitte.dk/en/entry-into-denmark/regarding-passengers-travelling-to-denmark-by-air
Danish bans all flights from UAE out of concern over unreliable COVID-19 testing   https://web.archive.org/web/20210208195433/https://travelbans.org/europe/denmark/

The Danish border closure – imposed on March 14 – remains in place for. Only travelers residents who qualify for a travel exception (called a “worthy purpose” by the Danish government) can enter Denmark. Some travel exceptions include having a valid residence permit for Denmark, attending a business meeting, or being the spouse, parent, or child of a Danish citizen or legal resident in Denmark.      To prevent the spreading of the British and South African mutations of COVID-19, the Danish government has imposed a flight ban on transportation of passengers from the entire world who are unable to present a negative COVID-19 test.    The flight ban will enter into force 9 January 2021 at 5pm and last until the end of 28 February 2021.    Link:https://web.archive.org/web/20210130124651/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/entry-into-denmark/persons-resident-in-countries-outside-of-denmark
Denmark extends ban on all flights from UAE until Feb 2  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208195433/https://travelbans.org/europe/denmark/

Persons resident outside of Denmark can only enter Denmark if they qualify with a worthy purpose and proof of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours before entry. Stricter entry requirements apply to permanent residents in the UK and South Africa. Worthy purposes include being a primary caregiver to a child or attending a funeral.     Coded as 4 as between worthy purpose and covid testing, the border is generally closed except for exceptional cases.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210206011018/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/entry-into-denmark/persons-resident-in-countries-outside-of-denmark

Aid package was extended to Jan 31, so still in place.    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20201124093950/https://em.dk/nyhedsarkiv/2020/oktober/covid-19-ny-aftale-udvider-hjaelpepakker-til-dansk-erhvervs-kultur-og-idraetsliv/

***Note updated to include details on options for compensation; still current to either Feb 28 2021 or March 7 2021 depending on type   Previous aid scheme is extended https://web.archive.org/web/20210206014917/https://virksomhedsguiden.dk/erhvervsfremme/content/temaer/coronavirus_og_din_virksomhed/ydelser/loenkompensation/8a8e7687-ab06-4524-aea6-dea26d6e95da/  There are currently four options for applying for salary compensation.  One option can all companies throughout Denmark apply for the period 9 December 2020 to 7 March 2021, regardless of  whether you have been affected by restrictions or not. You can  only  apply for the other if you have or have been prohibited from staying open and have not had any turnover on the CVR number or parking unit you are applying for in the period 9 December 2020 to 28 February 2021. The third option is targeted at companies that have been banned from being open during the period 6 November 2020 to 28 February 2021, and applies  as a general rule to  nightclubs, discos, venues with standing audiences and exhibition centers. The fourth option is targeted at companies that have been affected by restrictions in North Jutland in the period 6 November to 26 November 2020.

Can't find any current evidence of current debt or contract relief for households. A review of this indicator going back to August shows that it's been consistently recoded using data related to businesses, rather than households or individuals (hence the shift from 2G to 0).
No policy change  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130120218/https://coronasmitte.dk/
https://web.archive.org/web/20210206011344/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/

You should be tested if:    -You have symptoms that could be COVID-19  -You are told that you are in close contact with a person who is infected with a new coronavirus  -You are told that you must be tested prior to, for example, hospitalization, treatment or examination  -You are told that you must be tested as part of infection detection in the event of an outbreak, eg in primary schools, in day care institutions, in nursing homes, etc.  -You are told that you are 'another contact', and must be tested as soon as possible, eg via Infection | stop the app   -You go to work    The regions and the government have entered into agreements with private suppliers to conduct free rapid tests for all Danes. A rapid test (also called an antigen test) detects virus proteins in a sample and is taken by a nasal swab. The rapid test is less sensitive than the PCR test and therefore does not provide an equally reliable answer.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130131819/https://coronasmitte.dk/raad-og-regler/emner/test-

We recommend that you take a test if you have symptoms that could be COVID-19 or if you are a close or 'secondary' contact of someone infected with novel coronavirus. There are other situations in which it would be a good idea to get tested.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210206011726/https://www.sst.dk/en/English/Corona-eng/Symptoms_tested-positive-or-a-close-contact/On-being-tested

If you are infected with COVID-19, you are encouraged to contact the Danish Agency for Patient Safety Corona Detection as soon as possible on tel. 32 32 05 11. In any case, Corona Detection tries to contact the infected person within 24 hours after being notified of a positive test result from the Statens Serum Institut (or private test providers), to offer help in locating and contacting the close contacts who may be infected, and thus can also infect others. The infected person is offered help to call and advise the close contacts. It is voluntary if you want help with this task. As an infected person, you can also be responsible for informing close contacts and referring them. The Danish Agency for Patient Safety contacts citizens both by telephone and letter in e-Boks    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130131217/https://coronasmitte.dk/raad-og-regler/smitteopsporing

If you are infected with COVID-19, you are urged to contact the Patient Safety Safety Authority on 11/32 32 05 11 as soon as possible. In any case, Corona detection attempts to contact the infected person within 24 hours of being notified of a positive sample response from the National Serum Institute (or private test providers) to offer assistance in detecting and contacting close contacts who may be infected, and thus may also infect others.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210206012053/https://coronasmitte.dk/raad-og-regler/smitteopsporing

The current restrictions include the mandatory face mask use in indoor public areas.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130120629/https://www.thelocal.dk/20210127/dont-expect-denmark-to-reopen-at-start-of-february-minister    Wearing a face mask is obligatory:  - On public transport etc., including trains, busses, taxis and ferries, and at train stations and bus stops, etc.  - In establishments selling food, drinks or tobacco for consumption on-site.  - In retail shops, including supermarkets, shopping centres, department stores, bazaars and shopping arcades, takeaway restaurants, etc.  - Indoors in premises for cultural, sports and recreational activities, including museums, sports centres, fitness centres, art galleries, music venues, libraries, cultural centres, zoos, cinemas, theatres and clubs as well as job centres, citizen service centres, etc.   - Indoors in churches or other places of worship.  - At institutions of learning – such as preparatory education, upper secondary schools, adult and continuing education programmes, institutions of higher education, universities, folk high schools, night school, schools of music and arts, driving schools offering theory lessons, etc.  In public and private hospitals and clinics, independent therapists, municipal healthcare services, municipal and private nursing care and assisted living facilities, respite care facilities, as well as foster care facilities and institutions for people with mental disorders or special needs in the social care sector.  - While taking your driving test, including assessing the fitness to drive tests, when others are in the car with you.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130121532/https://www.sst.dk/en/English/Corona-eng/Prevent-infection/Face-masks

Wearing a face mask is obligatory: on public transport; in establishment selling food, drinks, tobacco; in retail shops; indoors in premises for cultural, sports and recreational activities; indoors in places of worship; at institutions of learning; in hospitals; when taking driving tests.  Wearing a mask is recommended: infected/at risk but have to leave home; at higher risk of severe illness from COVID and hard to social distance; visit someone at higher risk; at large gatherings; in situations where close face-to-face contact is unavoidable    https://web.archive.org/web/20210206002056/https://www.sst.dk/en/English/Corona-eng/Prevent%20infection/Face%20masks

On January 7, the government decided to resume contact education in general education schools, vocational schools and universities outside Harju County and Ida-Viru County as of January 11.     In Harju and Ida-Viru County, 1-4th, 9th and 12th grade students will return to in person teaching. The remaining grades will remain online.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210117193919/https://www.hm.ee/en/spread-covid-19-recommendations-educational-institutions

The government has decided to ease from today, 18 January, some of the restrictions imposed in Harju and Ida-Viru counties in December to limit the spread of the coronavirus, reports ERR.  In-person learning at all levels of education will be restored from 25 January.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210123122241/https://www.themayor.eu/en/a/view/estonia-eases-some-covid-19-restrictions-7025

Based on the proposals from the Government’s scientific advisory council and the Health Board, the Government members have decided to harmonise the restrictions established in Estonia due to extensive nationwide spread of the coronavirus.    The new restrictions will take effect in Harju and Ida-Viru County from Monday, 1 February, and in all other counties from Wednesday, 3 February.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210131125425/https://www.kriis.ee/en/news/government-harmonise-covid-19-restrictions-throughout-estonia

Currently all general, vocational and higher education institutions can operate in person given they follow various safety measures and there are no restrictions for pre-primary education.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210206132420/https://www.hm.ee/en/spread-covid-19-recommendations-educational-institutions

Harju and Ida-Viru counties -  Restaurants, cafes and other catering establishments may resume on-site service, staying open between 6 a.m. and 7 p.m. at up to 25 percent of their maximum capacity. Hobby activities and hobby education, refresher (additional) training and continuing education, youth work, sporting and training sessions will be allowed indoors as individual activities only. Inside museums and exhibition facilities, visitor numbers are capped at 50 percent of the premises’ capacity.   Alcoholic drinks cannot be sold from midnight to 10 a.m. until 26 January. From 27 January until 28 February, the ban on selling alcohol is extended from 10 p.m. to 10 a.m.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210123122241/https://www.themayor.eu/en/a/view/estonia-eases-some-covid-19-restrictions-7025

Based on the proposals from the Government’s scientific advisory council and the Health Board, the Government members have decided to harmonise the restrictions established in Estonia due to extensive nationwide spread of the coronavirus.    The new restrictions will take effect in Harju and Ida-Viru County from Monday, 1 February, and in all other counties from Wednesday, 3 February.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210131125425/https://www.kriis.ee/en/news/government-harmonise-covid-19-restrictions-throughout-estonia

New restrictions to prevent the spread of coronavirus have entered into force across Estonia on Wednesday (February 3). The rules were introduced in Harju and Ida-Viru counties on Monday but now apply across the country.  People can stay at restaurants, bars, cafes, night-clubs, bowling alleys, and elsewhere until 9 p.m. No restrictions will be established for take-away sales at catering establishments.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206132259/https://news.err.ee/1608093460/new-coronavirus-restrictions-enter-into-force-across-estonia

Harju and Ida-Viru counties -  Public meetings and events, including conferences, theatre performances, concerts and movie screenings, are prohibited indoors. Outdoors, they can be attended in groups of up to ten people, with no contact between groups allowed. A public outdoor event must be over by 10 p.m.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210123122241/https://www.themayor.eu/en/a/view/estonia-eases-some-covid-19-restrictions-7025
