General levels of contact tracing seem low, as:    "Just 1.9% of the Polish population have downloaded the government’s COVID-19 contact tracing app since its launch in June. That is one of the lowest levels of take-up among European countries. Such low adoption means that the app will not be effective, according to experts. The system, which cost around 2.5 million zloty (€0.6 million) to develop, has also been hit by concerns over privacy and functionality."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210120143636/https://notesfrompoland.com/2020/09/11/uptake-of-covid-contact-tracing-app-under-2-in-poland-among-the-lowest-rates-in-europe/    "Contact tracing using epidemiological interviews is carried out for people who may have had contact with an infected person according to the epidemiological criteria of COVID-19 case explained above. Data are gathered by the local sanitary inspection units. The Minister of Health publishes aggregated information about new cases, deaths and recoveries via its Twitter account. Data is not disaggregated into age groups or by geographic location."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210120143626/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/poland/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.4+Monitoring+and+surveillance&Type=Section

***Recoded from 3G to 2G; while masks are required in many public spaces, they are not required at others (see list of exemptions below)     Covering the mouth and nose in public spaces is obligatory throughout the entire country!    It is mandatory to cover your mouth and nose in such places as:    -on streets, roads and in town squares, within cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, vehicle parking areas, forest car parks,  -in buses, trams and trains,  -in shops, malls, banks, markets and post offices  -in cinemas and theatres,  -at physician’s offices, in outpatient clinics and hospitals, in massage and tattoo parlours  -in churches, at schools and universities,  -In government offices (when going there to take care of certain matters) and other civic centres.    Where is it not mandatory to cover your mouth and nose? In forests, parks, green squares, botanical gardens, historic gardens, family community gardens and on beaches as well as while travelling by private car.    Important!  Exemption from the obligation to cover the mouth and nose is limited only to persons who have a medical certificate or a document confirming:    -a pervasive developmental disorder,  -a mental disorder,  -moderate, severe or profound intellectual disability,  -difficulties in uncovering the mouth or nose on their own.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210127093533/https://www.gov.pl/web/coronavirus/temporary-limitations
https://web.archive.org/web/20210210135405/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

The State of Emergency was decreed until January 30th, defining circulation restrictions from 0:00 on January 15th (in mainland Portugal).  All educational establishments will remain open and continue to operate as they have been until now.  According to a document distributed during the briefing of the Head of Government, the measure applies to nurseries, schools and universities.  Note: In certain municipalities in the Azores schools remain fully closed (all levels) - reason why the code has remain unchanged despite these measures.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118153435/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal http://web.archive.org/web/20210118163525/https://www.theportugalnews.com/news/2021-01-13/schools-to-remain-open-in-full-operation/57684

Mainland Portugal : "The Prime Minister announced a 15-day school break (for all levels), which takes effect on Friday (January 22), which is justified by a "precautionary principle" because of the increase in the number of cases of the most contagious variant of SARS-CoV-2 , which have grown from around 8% prevalence in the past week to around 20% today."   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130172354/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2021-01-21-Covid-19.-Governo-decide-fechar-todos-os-niveis-de-ensino-por-15-dias  Madeira Island : "Face-to-face classes for students in the 3rd Cycle and Secondary Education are suspended in all schools in the Autonomous Region of Madeira  until February 21 .  - All other levels of education : daycare centers / kindergartens / pre-school / 1st and 2nd cycles / special and professional education maintain their activities in person . - All out-of-school activities, in person, are suspended until February 21st."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130172656/https://www.madeira.gov.pt/Covid19/DecisoesExcecionaisCovid19  Note: Since in Madeira, schools are only closed for some levels the code remains unchanged.

Mainland Portugal:  The Government closed the schools again, due to the exponential increase of cases of covid-19 in the country, and, after a suspension of the teaching activities, the classes will resume at a distance as early as next February 8th.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210206172748/https://tvi24.iol.pt/sociedade/ensino-a-distancia/telescola-estes-sao-os-novos-horarios-para-as-aulas-em-casa    Madeira  Face-to-face classes for students in the 3rd Cycle and Secondary Education are suspended in all schools in the Autonomous Region of Madeira  until February 21. All other levels of education : daycare centers / kindergartens / pre-school / 1st and 2nd cycles / special and professional education maintain their activities in person.  Link:https://web.archive.org/web/20210206170727/https://www.madeira.gov.pt/Covid19/DecisoesExcecionaisCovid19    Azores: Schools appear open in Sao Miguel. In the municipalities of Ponta Delgada, Lagoa, Nordeste and Povoação, the remaining levels of education will continue to have distance classes. In the municipalities considered to be at high risk for the spread of covid-19, Vila Franca do Campo and Ribeira Grande, all schools, at all levels of education, will remain closed.  Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206172645/https://edu.azores.gov.pt/regressoseguro/

"The State of Emergency was decreed until January 30th, defining circulation restrictions from 0:00 on January 15th in mainland Portugal.  "Establishments and services open to the public: essential goods stores, grocery stores,, supermarkets and hypermarkets may operate without time restrictions; health services, offices, dentists and pharmacies; restaurants and cafes may only operate on a take-away or home delivery basis; fairs and markets are only allowed to sell food products.  Establishments and services closed to the public: hairdressers / barber shops; gyms closed; museums, cultural and leisure spaces; prohibited events."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118153435/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal  "The autonomous region of Madeira is currently in a state of calamity. Measures are in place to limit the spread of the virus. (...) Shops and others commercial premises, with the exception of pharmacies, health centres and petrol stations, will close at 6pm on weekdays and at 5pm on weekends and public holidays. Restaurants can remain open until 10pm for takeaway and food delivery services only."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  Note: Since in Madeira, non-essential services are allowed to be open and restrictions apply to the opening schedules - meaning these are not fully closed - the T(argeted) flag was kept.

Mainland Portugal : "The State of Emergency was decreed until 30 January, defining circulation restrictions from 0:00 on 15 January (...) Establishments and services closed to the public: hairdressers / barber shops; gyms; sports facilities, even outdoors; museums, cultural and leisure spaces;    Source: https://archive.vn/japFQ#selection-2317.0-2317.150    Azores : "The regional government has implemented a regional state of alert. Measures are in place throughout the archipelago to limit the spread of the virus.  There are 3 levels of risk in the Azores – low, medium and high."     From midnight on Saturday, January 30:    Low Risk islands: "Closure of all drinks and similar establishments, with dance spaces"  Medium Risk Islands : "Closure of all restaurants, drinks and similar establishments at *8:00 pm*, with or without a show and with or without terrace service, including spaces for holding events, except for take-away or home delivery purposes (...) Prohibition of the sale of alcoholic beverages after 8:00 pm, unless in restaurant service"  High risk Islands : "Closure of daycare centers and ATL; (...) Closure of gymnasiums and covered swimming pools, with the practice of sports in these spaces being prohibited; Closure of casinos and gambling establishments"    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183029/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8896  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183311/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8888  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183443/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8891    Madeira : "Until February 21, all activities of an industrial, commercial and service nature must, imperatively, close:    - During the days of the week : until 18h.  - Saturdays, Sundays and municipal holidays : until 17h.    Until February 21, all gambling establishments, casinos, bingo or similar, must close:  - Weekends : until 17h.  - During the week : at 6 pm.    Until the 21st of February restaurants are allowed to open:    - During the days of the week (Monday to Friday): until 6pm.  - Weekends : until 17h, and the takeaway service and home deliveries will be closed from that time."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130172656/https://www.madeira.gov.pt/Covid19/DecisoesExcecionaisCovid19    Note: Since in Madeira AND in low risk islands in the Azores establishments are allowed to be open (despite the restrictions in terms of schedules) the flag (targeted remains unchanged).

Mainland portugal: Shops and other commercial premises, with the exception of supermarkets, grocery and hardware stores, pharmacies and petrol stations, are closed. Stores that remain open have shorter trading hours, as follows:  Weekdays – all shops and supermarkets close at 8pm  Weekends – shops close at 1pm; supermarkets and grocery stores close at 5pm  Restaurants and cafés are closed, except for takeaways and food delivery services. Food that is collected must be eaten at home. The sale of alcohol and other drinks is prohibited. Mainland Portugal : "The State of Emergency was decreed until 1 March (...)    Establishments and services open to the public  - Essential goods shops, grocery shops, supermarkets and hypermarkets may operate without time restrictions;  - Health services, offices, dentists and pharmacies;  - Restaurants and cafes may only operate on a take-away or home delivery basis;  - Fairs and markets are allowed for food sales only.  Shops must close by 8 pm on weekdays. At the weekend, shops should close at 1 pm, except supermarkets and food shops that may be open to the public until 5 pm.  The time restriction is not applicable to accommodation units, local accommodation, rent-a-car and establishments located inside airports after the passenger security check.  In hotel bars and restaurants, operation is permitted for the purpose of room-service or take-away.    Establishments and services closed to the public  - Hairdressers / barber shops;  - Gyms closed;  - sports facilities, even outdoors;  - Museums, cultural and leisure spaces"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213171414/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal    Madeira:     "Until February 21, all activities of an industrial, commercial and service nature must, imperatively, close until 5 pm.    Exceptions include:    - Workshop pharmacies;  - Clinics, medical and veterinary offices, medical services or other health and social support services;  - Oxygen and medical gas services at home;  - Fuel filling stations (only for filling vehicles);  - Bakery sector;  - Port activity of loading and unloading of goods and their distribution;  - The commercial establishments located inside the airports of Madeira and Porto Santo, after checking the security of passengers;  - Tourist developments and local accommodation establishments.    Gambling Establishments : Until February 21, all gambling establishments, casinos, bingo or similar, must close until 5 pm.    Restaurants, Bars and Similar Establishments : Until February 21, they must close until 5 pm.    Between February 15 and 19, 2021, it will be allowed to operate between 5 pm and 10 pm, only for making meals, exclusively for home delivery."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213145430/https://www.madeira.gov.pt/Covid19/DecisoesExcecionaisCovid19    Azores:     "The Azores will apply, as of 8 pm this Friday and during the Carnival period, traffic restrictions, banning parties and limiting trade and catering hours, to control the spread of Covid-19.    The measures, which will be applied in all municipalities of the archipelago, come into force at 8 pm and extend until 11:59 pm on Tuesday, although they are more restrictive at the weekend.    (...) Between 8:00 pm on Friday and 11:59 pm on Sunday, there is an obligation to close “all non-essential trade, considering as essential trade establishments that provide essential goods or other goods considered essential, or those that provide services first need ”.    During this period, the “restaurants, beverages and similar establishments are also closed, with the exception of take-away and home delivery services”.    On Monday and Tuesday, restaurants, beverages and similar establishments can open until 3:00 pm, after that time, only take-away and home delivery."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213150934/https://observador.pt/2021/02/12/acores-com-restricoes-a-circulacao-e-limitacoes-de-horarios-no-carnaval/

Mainland Portugal: "The State of Emergency was decreed until January 30th, defining circulation restrictions from 0:00 on January 15th. There will be a general duty of home retreat. The movement and concentration of groups of more than 5 people is prohibited, in private or public spaces, unless they belong to the same household. (...) Public events are prohibited".  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118153435/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal  Madeira: "Due to the epidemiological evolution in the Autonomous Region of Madeira, and according to Government Resolution No. 19/2021, the Regional Government of Madeira has adopted a set of new preventive measures, applicable with immediate effect as from the 13th of January, and which will remain in force until the 31st of this month. Gatherings of more than 5 persons are prohibited, unless from the same family unit, on the public way, or in any other public area (...)"  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210111082652/http://www.visitmadeira.pt/en-gb/useful-info/corona-virus-%28covid-19%29/information-to-visitors-%28covid-19%29  Azores: On the Regional Government website, that includes the list of social and cultural events, the large majority of events for the month of January were either cancelled or will take place online, due to the COVID-19 restrictions currently in place.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210119141108/https://agendacores.pt/

Mainland Portugal : "There will be a general duty of home retreat. It will not be allowed to circulate in public spaces and roads, with the exception of authorized travel (...) Prohibited events "    Source: https://archive.vn/japFQ#selection-2317.0-2317.150    Madeira: "limitation to 5 people in the access, circulation or permanence in the public road and in other spaces of commercial and restaurant nature, except if they belong to the same household;  limitation to 5 people per group, unless belonging to the same household, in areas of restoration of shopping centers and restaurants, cafes and pastry shops 300m from schools; celebrations and other events that involve an agglomeration of people in excess of 5 people are prohibited, unless they belong to the same household, including cultural shows or events of any nature, with the exception of religious ceremonies, provided that limitation of capacity contained in paragraph 10 of Resolution no. 839/2020, of 5 November."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130172656/https://www.madeira.gov.pt/Covid19/DecisoesExcecionaisCovid19    Azores : "The regional government has implemented a regional state of alert. Measures are in place throughout the archipelago to limit the spread of the virus.  There are 3 levels of risk in the Azores – low, medium and high."     From midnight on Saturday, January 30:    Low Risk islands: "Suspension of the holding of public events promoted by the regional administration, including public institutes and public companies, extending this recommendation to all public entities, namely local authorities, as well as to private sector entities, urging the non-holding of events open to the public"  Medium Risk Islands : "Suspension of opening to the public at sporting events and competitions"  High risk Islands : "Limitation of gatherings on the public road of a maximum number of four people, unless they are from the same household"    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183029/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8896  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183311/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8888  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183443/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8891

No policy change    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210206173856/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

"The State of Emergency was decreed until January 30th, defining circulation restrictions from 0:00 on January 15th.  There will be a general duty of home retreat. It will not be allowed to travel, except for authorized travel namely for acquisition of essential goods and services; access to public services; professional activities; health reasons; assistance to vulnerable people", among others.  "The autonomous region of Madeira is currently in a state of calamity. Measures are in place to limit the spread of the virus. Until further notice, a curfew is in place: on weekdays from 7pm to 5am and  on weekends and public holidays from 6pm to 5am"  "The regional government has implemented a regional state of alert. Measures are in place throughout the archipelago to limit the spread of the virus.  There are 3 levels of risk in the Azores – low, medium and high. The island of São Miguel is classified as high risk. On this island, until further notice, you are obliged to stay at home as follows: on weekdays from 8pm to 5am and n weekends from 3pm to 5am."  Note: Since the measures in the Azores DO NOT apply to all 9 islands (currently only 1 has a curfew a T(argeted) flag has been selected.  Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118153435/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-

Mainland Portugal : "There will be a general duty of home retreat. It will not be allowed to circulate in public spaces and roads, with the exception of authorized travel on which the following stand out: acquisition of essential goods and services; access to public services; professional activities (if accompanied by a statement); health reasons; assistance to vulnerable people; school attendance; short walks for physical activity, individually or with members of the same household; pet walk; travelling necessary to enter or leave the mainland, including those necessary to travel to and from the place of accommodation; homecoming within the framework of permitted situations; refuelling at petrol stations as part of permitted journeys."    Madeira : "The autonomous region of Madeira is currently in a state of calamity. Measures are in place to limit the spread of the virus. Until further notice, you are obliged to stay at home: on weekdays from 7pm to 5am and on weekends and public holidays from 6pm to 5am"    Azores: "The autonomous region of the Azores is currently in a state of emergency. Measures are in place throughout the archipelago to limit the spread of the virus. There are 3 levels of risk in the Azores – low, medium and high. Each level has its own restrictions. The island of São Miguel is currently classified as high risk. The remaining islands (8) are classified as low risk. In São Miguel, until further notice, you are obliged to stay at home as follows: on weekdays from 8pm to 5am and on weekends from 3pm to 5am.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130165532/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  https://archive.vn/japFQ#selection-2317.0-2339.62    Note: Since the measures in the Azores DO NOT apply to all 9 islands (currently only 1 has a curfew a T(argeted) flag has been selected.

Mainland Portugal : "The State of Emergency was decreed until 30 January, defining circulation restrictions from 0:00 on 15 January. (...) There will be a general duty of home retreat. It will not be allowed to circulate in public spaces and roads, with the exception of authorized travel on which the following stand out: acquisition of essential goods and services; access to public services; professional activities (if accompanied by a statement); health reasons; assistance to vulnerable people; short walks for physical activity, individually or with members of the same household; pet walk; travelling necessary to enter or leave the mainland, including those necessary to travel to and from the place of accommodation; homecoming within the framework of permitted situations; refuelling at petrol stations as part of permitted journeys."    Source: https://archive.vn/japFQ#selection-2285.0-2285.111    Madeira: "Until February 21, circulation on public roads is prohibited:     - During the days of the week : between 19h and 05h the next day.  - Saturdays, Sundays and local holidays : between 18h and 05h the next day"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130172656/https://www.madeira.gov.pt/Covid19/DecisoesExcecionaisCovid19      Azores:  "The regional government has implemented a regional state of alert. Measures are in place throughout the archipelago to limit the spread of the virus.  There are 3 levels of risk in the Azores – low, medium and high."     From Saturday, January 30:    Low and medium risk islands : NO stay at home requirements.  High risk islands: "Prohibition of pedestrian, car, motorized or similar circulation on public roads between 8:00 pm and 5:00 am the following day on weekdays and between 3:00 pm and 5:00 am the day after weekend, except as provided in paragraph 4"    NOTE: In low and middle risk islands in the Azores there are no stay at home requirements which is why the code remains unchanged despite the additional measures announced by the regional government.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183029/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8896  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183311/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8888  http://web.archive.org/web/20210130183443/https://destinoseguro.azores.gov.pt/?page_id=8891

Mainland Portugal:  Currently in a ‘state of emergency.’ The Portuguese government has put in place a series of measures to control the spread of the virus, including a national lockdown. You are instructed to stay at home, except:  - to buy food and other essential items  - to go to work exceptionally, if your professional activity is not compatible with working from home  - to go to a hospital, health centre or dental clinic  - to go to a veterinary clinic or walk a pet  - to carry out caring or similar duties  - to take short periods of exercise outdoors (individually, not in groups)    Maderia:  Currently in a state of calamity. Measures are in place to limit the spread of the virus. Until further notice, you are obliged to stay at home:  - on weekdays from 7pm to 5am  - on weekends and public holidays from 6pm to 5am    The Azores  Currently in a state of emergency. Measures are in place throughout the archipelago to limit the spread of the virus. There are 3 levels of risk in the Azores – low, medium and high. Each level has its own restrictions. In the high-risk municipalities of Ribeira Grande and Vila Franca do Campo on the island of São Miguel, you are obliged to stay at home until further notice, as follows:  - On weekdays from 8pm to 5am.  - On weekends from 3pm to 5am    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210206170145/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-

Mainland Portugal:    "The State of Emergency was decreed until 1 March (...) There will be a general duty of home retreat. It will not be allowed to circulate in public spaces and roads, with the exception of authorized travel on which the following stand out:  - acquisition of essential goods and services;  - access to public services;  - professional activities (if accompanied by a statement);  - health reasons;  - assistance to vulnerable people;  - school attendance;  - short walks for physical activity, individually or with members of the same household;  - pet walk;  - travelling necessary to enter or leave the mainland, including those necessary to travel to and from the place of accommodation;  - homecoming within the framework of permitted situations;  - refuelling at petrol stations as part of permitted journeys.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213171414/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal    Madeira :     "Until February 21, circulation on public roads is prohibited between 6:00 pm and 5:00 am the following day.    Exceptions:    - Professional travel, as attested by statement;  - Health professionals and other workers from health and social support institutions;  - Civil protection agents, military personnel, inspectors from the Regional Economic Activities Authority (ARAE) and security forces;  - Cult ministers;  - Diplomatic and consular mission staff;  - Displacement for health reasons;  - Emergency reception of victims of domestic violence or trafficking in human beings;  - Assistance to vulnerable persons or persons with disabilities;  - Fulfill parental responsibilities;  - Urgent medical-veterinary assistance;  - Exercise of freedom of the press;  - Homecoming within the scope of admitted travel;  - Travel to the airport to board and disembark passengers;  - Travel by public transport, taxis and TVDE, within the scope of the exceptions allowed here;  - Bakery professionals, for night work;  - Other urgent reasons, provided that it can be shown that they cannot be delayed."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213145430/https://www.madeira.gov.pt/Covid19/DecisoesExcecionaisCovid19    Azores:     "The Azores will apply, as of 8 pm this Friday (February 12) and during the Carnival period, traffic restrictions, banning parties and limiting trade and catering hours, to control the spread of Covid-19.    The measures, which will be applied in ALL municipalities of the archipelago, come into force at 8 pm and extend until 11:59 pm on Tuesday, although they are more restrictive at the weekend.    (...) In the same period, traffic on public roads between 8:00 pm and 5:00 am will also be prohibited, with the exceptions provided for by law, such as travel for health reasons, to work and to purchase essential goods".    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213150934/https://observador.pt/2021/02/12/acores-com-restricoes-a-circulacao-e-limitacoes-de-horarios-no-carnaval/

Individuals should only travel between the islands (Madeira and the Azores) for essential purposes. If one has to travel from São Miguel or Terceira to any of the other islands in the archipelago (Azores), a negative RT-PCR COVID-19 test from, at most, 72 hours before travelling and completing a passenger questionnaire before depart are required.     In mainland Portugal, there are no specific restrictions on mobility to cross land borders but the Government recommends only leaving home only for essential travel (T flag applied since the travel restrictions do not apply).    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  http://web.archive.org/web/20210118153435/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

Inter-island travel  "You should only travel between islands if your journey is essential. If you have to travel and you are travelling from São Miguel or Terceira to any of the other islands in the archipelago, you will need to have a negative RT-PCR COVID-19 test from, at most, 72 hours before you travel and show the negative result when you board, and complete a passenger questionnaire before you depart."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130165532/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-  Movement between municipalities in mainland Portugal during the weekend will be prohibited, between 8pm on Friday, January 29 to 5am on Monday, February 1.  Source: https://archive.vn/japFQ  Note: Since during this weekend restrictions apply to the entire Portuguese territory (mainland + Madeira + Azores) the code was upgraded to 2G.

You should only travel between islands if your journey is essential. If you have to travel and you are travelling from São Miguel or Terceira to any of the other islands in the archipelago, you will need to have a negative RT-PCR COVID-19 test from, at most, 72 hours before you travel and show the negative result when you board, and complete a passenger questionnaire before you depart.    Note: According to the codebook "Some examples that could indicate a 2:  (...) requirement of negative test result" hence the 2T code.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210206170145/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-

Mainland Portugal : "Movement between municipalities at the weekend will be prohibited, between 8pm on friday, February 5, to 5am on Monday, February 8."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210207062815/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal    Azores and Madeira Islands:    "You should only travel between islands if your journey is essential. If you have to travel and you are travelling from São Miguel or Terceira to any of the other islands in the archipelago, you will need to have a negative RT-PCR COVID-19 test from, at most, 72 hours before you travel and show the negative result when you board, and complete a passenger questionnaire before you depart."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130165532/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-    "Madeira : "All passengers, whether Portuguese or foreign, with trips scheduled for RAM, can perform  PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction)  tests at COVID-19,  free of charge ,  in several cities in the country. Currently, there are  33  sample collection stations for testing.    When planning your trip to Madeira and Porto Santo, it is important to know the local rules in force within the scope of the prevention and containment of COVID-19, namely:     1. Epidemiological Survey  All passengers must complete the mandatory epidemiological survey, made available by the Regional Health Authority, on the digital platform madeirasafe.com (...)"    2. Thermal screening  All passengers disembarked at airports in the Autonomous Region of Madeira, without exception, are subject to thermal screening.     3. Test the COVID-19  All passengers who, when disembarking, carry a negative PCR test to COVID-19, carried out within 72 hours prior to boarding, in laboratories certified by national or international authorities, can proceed to their destination.   For their part, passengers who have not undergone PCR testing at the origin will do so on arrival at the airport, then proceed to their destination, where they must wait, in confinement, for the result to be obtained, for an estimated period of 12h (...)     3.1 Children  They are exempt from being subjected to testing in childhood and pre-adolescence, except:     • Children from 12 years old, under the prior opinion of the Health Authorities;  • Children with criteria for suspected COVID disease 19;  • Children whose family members or companions are suspected cases;  • Other situations validated by the Health Authorities.     3.2 Second Test  All travelers residing in the territory of the Autonomous Region of Madeira (RAM), as well as Madeiran emigrants, their families, and students attending higher education establishments or in Mobility Programs, who disembark at Madeira and Porto Santo airports, on flights coming from any territory outside the RAM, they are required to perform the second PCR test to screen for SARS-CoV-2, between the fifth and seventh days after the first test is performed, and must guarantee, in the period between disembarkation and second test, prophylactic isolation at home and full compliance with the surveillance and self-reporting of symptoms and COVID-19 prevention measures.  Travelers / tourists, non-residents, who travel to RAM on a leisure / tourism basis are exempt from this procedure."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213175534/http://www.visitmadeira.pt/pt-pt/info-uteis/corona-virus-%28covid-19%29/informacoes-aos-visitantes-%28covid-19%29    Note: Since during this weekend restrictions apply to the entire Portuguese territory (mainland + Madeira + Azores) the code was upgraded to 2G.

Inter-island travel    You should only travel between islands if your journey is essential. If you have to travel and you are travelling from São Miguel to any of the other islands in the archipelago, you will need to    - have a negative RT-PCR COVID-19 test from, at most, 72 hours before you travel and show the negative result when you board, and  - complete a passenger questionnaire before you depart"    Note: According to the codebook "Some examples that could indicate a 2: (...) requirement of negative test result" hence the 2T code.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210210160304/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus

Mainland Portugal : Mainland Portugal : "The State of Emergency was decreed until 1 March, defining circulation restrictions. (...) Movement between municipalities at the weekend will be prohibited, between 8pm on Friday to 5am on Monday."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213171414/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal    Madeira and the Azores : You should only travel between islands if your journey is essential. If you have to travel and you are travelling from São Miguel to any of the other islands in the archipelago, you will need to    - have a negative RT-PCR COVID-19 test from, at most, 72 hours before you travel and show the negative result when you board, and  - complete a passenger questionnaire before you depart"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210210160304/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus    Madeira : "All passengers, whether Portuguese or foreign, with trips scheduled for RAM, can perform  PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction)  tests at COVID-19,  free of charge ,  in several cities in the country. Currently, there are  33  sample collection stations for testing.    When planning your trip to Madeira and Porto Santo, it is important to know the local rules in force within the scope of the prevention and containment of COVID-19, namely:     1. Epidemiological Survey  All passengers must complete the mandatory epidemiological survey, made available by the Regional Health Authority, on the digital platform madeirasafe.com (...)"    2. Thermal screening  All passengers disembarked at airports in the Autonomous Region of Madeira, without exception, are subject to thermal screening.     3. Test the COVID-19  All passengers who, when disembarking, carry a negative PCR test to COVID-19, carried out within 72 hours prior to boarding, in laboratories certified by national or international authorities, can proceed to their destination.   For their part, passengers who have not undergone PCR testing at the origin will do so on arrival at the airport, then proceed to their destination, where they must wait, in confinement, for the result to be obtained, for an estimated period of 12h (...)     3.1 Children  They are exempt from being subjected to testing in childhood and pre-adolescence, except:     • Children from 12 years old, under the prior opinion of the Health Authorities;  • Children with criteria for suspected COVID disease 19;  • Children whose family members or companions are suspected cases;  • Other situations validated by the Health Authorities.     3.2 Second Test  All travelers residing in the territory of the Autonomous Region of Madeira (RAM), as well as Madeiran emigrants, their families, and students attending higher education establishments or in Mobility Programs, who disembark at Madeira and Porto Santo airports, on flights coming from any territory outside the RAM, they are required to perform the second PCR test to screen for SARS-CoV-2, between the fifth and seventh days after the first test is performed, and must guarantee, in the period between disembarkation and second test, prophylactic isolation at home and full compliance with the surveillance and self-reporting of symptoms and COVID-19 prevention measures.  Travelers / tourists, non-residents, who travel to RAM on a leisure / tourism basis are exempt from this procedure."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213175534/http://www.visitmadeira.pt/pt-pt/info-uteis/corona-virus-%28covid-19%29/informacoes-aos-visitantes-%28covid-19%29    Note: Since during this weekend restrictions apply to the entire Portuguese territory (mainland + Madeira + Azores) the code was upgraded to 2G.

"Air travel to and from Portugal is allowed to: - European Union countries; - Schengen Associated Countries - Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland – and the United Kingdom; - Australia, China (including Hong Kong and Macao), South Korea, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand and Uruguay. It is not necessary to present the COVID-19 Test on these flights, unless the destinations are the archipelagos of Madeira or the Azores. - Only passengers on flights from the UK who are nationals or legally resident in Portugal are allowed to enter national territory.  United Kingdom (UK): - All passengers must present a negative test to COVID 19. - Upon arrival in the national territory, citizens who do not have proof of negative test results will be sent by the competent authorities to be carried out inside the airport. In this case, citizens will have to remain in isolation, under the terms defined by health authorities. - On flights from the UK to Madeira, passengers who are not tested negative should do so on arrival and between 5 and 7 days and should await the results in prophylactic isolation."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118153435/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal

In addition to restrictions previously in place, "The government has decided to suspend flights to and from Brazil from 00:00 on Friday due to the evolution of the pandemic, the increase in cases of infection by the new coronavirus and the detection of new strains.  "Until February 14, all flights, commercial or private, of all airlines to and from Brazil are suspended. The rules now laid down also apply to flights to and from the UK," the Home Office (MAI) said in a statement."  Source: https://archive.vn/0HexI

1. Which countries are air traffic authorized to?  1. Flights to and from countries belonging to the EU and countries associated with the Schengen Area (Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland and Switzerland)  2. Flights from Australia, China, South Korea, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand, and the special administrative regions of Hong Kong and Macau;  3. Flights that are not to / from EU countries or associated with the Schengen Area, exclusively for essential trips   4. Flights intended to allow the return to Portugal of nationals or foreign citizens holding a residence permit in Portugal and flights intended to allow the return to their countries of foreign citizens who are in Portugal, provided that they are promoted by the competent authorities of such countries;  NOTE: FLIGHTS TO AND FROM THE UNITED KINGDOM AND BRAZIL ARE SUSPENDED UNTIL 11:59 PM ON FEBRUARY 14, 2021 ( Order No. 1125-D / 2021 ).    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210206174157/https://portaldascomunidades.mne.gov.pt/pt/noticias/faq-s-viagens-para-portugal-conselhos-aos-emigrantes

"Travel outside the mainland  It is prohibited to travel outside the continental territory by Portuguese citizens, by any means, whether by road, rail, air, river or maritime, except for essential travel, among which the following stand out: professional activities (properly documented); leaving the mainland of Portuguese citizens residing in other countries; exceptionally, for the purpose of family reunion of spouses and family members up to 1st grade; travel to the Autonomous Regions of the Azores and Madeira.     Air travel to and from Portugal is allowed to:  - European Union countries;  - Schengen Associated Countries - Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland;  - Australia, China (including Hong Kong and Macao), South Korea, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand and Uruguay.    Passengers from countries with an incidence rate of 500 cases or more per 100,000 inhabitants in the last 14 days - Czech Republic, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Estonia, Ireland, Lithuania, Latvia – must present a negative test to COVID-19 (RT-PCR), carried out within 72 hours before boarding time and must comply, after entry in mainland Portugal, a period of prophylactic isolation of 14 days, at home or in a place indicated by health authorities. Prophylactic isolation does not apply to passengers on essential travels and whose length of stay in national territory, certified by return ticket, does not exceed 48 hours.    Passengers coming from countries that have a incidence between 150 and 500 cases per 100,000 inhabitants in the last 14 days - Germany, Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Croatia, Denmark, France, Hungary, Italy, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Poland, Romania, Sweden, Switzerland – must present a negative test to COVID-19 (RT-PCR), carried out within 72 hours before boarding time.     (...) All commercial or private flights between Portugal and the United Kingdom and between Portugal and Brazil are suspended. Except for the right of entry for national citizens and their families and holders of residence permits in Portugal, only on flights of a humanitarian nature for the purpose of repatriation of those citizens. These passengers will have to present, at the time of departure, proof of a RT-PCR test with a negative result, carried out within 72 hours prior to departure time. Upon arriving in the national territory, they must comply with a period of 14 days of quarantine at home, or in a place indicated by the health authorities."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213143309/https://www.visitportugal.com/en/content/covid-19-measures-implemented-portugal
No announced change in policy   https://web.archive.org/web/20210206180005/https://www.portugal.gov.pt/pt/gc22/comunicacao/noticias?p=1

The Portuguese government has approved a moratorium on bank loan repayments for households and companies affected by the coronavirus outbreak which has been extended until end-September 2021. The date by which households and companies can avail themselves of the moratoria was recently extended until the end of March 2021.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213155040/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#P    The Government will support all families, irrespectively of their income, during the general lockdown (that started on Friday, January 15), by paying 10% of their electricity bills. The measure will cost between 20 and 25 million euros (monthly). For low income families, the reduction in the electricity bill might reach 40%.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118164726/https://eco.sapo.pt/2021/01/12/governo-apoia-familias-com-cerca-de-10-da-fatura-da-luz/    Note: The code remains unchanged because there is no freezing in financial obligations (meaning, in case individuals do not pay their bill the energy supply can still be disconnected).

"On mainland Portugal and in the autonomous regions of Madeira and the Azores, you must wear a face mask in all enclosed spaces. You should wear your face covering when you enter the building and keep it on until you leave.    On mainland Portugal and in the Azores, you must also wear a face mask outdoors where it is not possible to maintain a 2m social distance from people outside your family group. In Madeira and Porto Santo, the use of a face mask outdoors is mandatory, except when driving, exercising, while on the beach or walking the recommended routes in forest and mountain areas.    These measures apply to everyone over the age of 10 on mainland Portugal and in the Azores, and over the age of 5 in Madeira and Porto Santo."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210118230326/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/portugal/coronavirus-

Phase 1 From December 2020: Health professionals involved in patient care, Professionals in the armed forces, security forces and critical services, Professionals and residents in Residential Structures for the Elderly (ERPI) and similar institutions, Professionals and users of the National Integrated, Continuing Care Network (RNCCI).    From February 2021 : People aged =50 years, with at least one of the following pathologies: Cardiac insufficiency Coronary heart disease, Renal insufficiency (Glomerular Filtration Rate <60ml / min)  (COPD) or chronic respiratory disease under ventilatory support and / or long-term oxygen therapy.  People aged 80 and over. Religious gatherings, worship, cultural events and sporting events are allowed with conditions and limited numbers of people. Vaccinations expected to start in March 2021

Priština said on Wednesday it secured two million anti-coronavirus vaccines, with the first shipment of Pfizer’s injections expected in February and planned to vaccinate 20,000 people daily, according to Prime Minister Avdulah Hoti, and Health Minister Armend Zemaj.  Hoti added that besides 535,000 Pfizer-BioNtech vaccines, some 600,000 doses would come from Austria and an additional 720,000 based on the World Health Organization COVAX programme.    The vaccination for 1.8 million people in Kosovo will be free of charge and voluntarily.  According to Hoti, the first to be vaccinated will be health system employees and people over 65.  Notes: A & C    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130101810/https://rs.n1info.com/english/news/kosovo-to-get-two-million-anti-coronavirus-vaccines-first-shipment-in-february/

No change found as the present policy still applies. The vaccination for 1.8 million people in Kosovo will be free of charge and voluntarily.  According to Hoti, the first to be vaccinated will be health system employees and people over 65.  Notes: A & C    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210130101810/https://rs.n1info.com/english/news/kosovo-to-get-two-million-anti-coronavirus-vaccines-first-shipment-in-february/

No change found - current policy still applies. Vaccinations will be free of charge and voluntary and will be deployed as soon as they are available from Covax..  The first to be vaccinated will be health system employees and people over 65. Groups A, C (with vaccines supplied via Covax - type TBD).

According to the ministerial order 3090/8.01.2021, teaching activities that require the physical presence in preschool, primary, secondary, high school and post-secondary education units are suspended for the period 11th-29th of January 2021.  Links: https://archive.fo/wip/dYf7v

According to the ministerial order 3090/8.01.2021, teaching activities that require the physical presence in preschool, primary, secondary, high school and post-secondary education units are suspended for the period 11th-29th of January 2021.  Links: https://archive.fo/wip/dYf7v

A decision on reopening the schools in Romania will be taken on February 2, after a review of the country's coronavirus situation, prime minister Florin Citu said on Tuesday, January 19.   He also said that "if things remain as they are" when it comes to the evolution of the COVID-19 pandemic in Romania, schools will reopen on February 8, under the conditions announced by president Klaus Iohannis.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210123124020/https://www.romania-insider.com/decision-schools-reopening-early-february-2021

According to the ministerial order 3090/8.01.2021, teaching activities that require the physical presence in preschool, primary, secondary, high school and post-secondary education units are suspended for the period 11th-29th of January 2021. Between 30th of January and 7th of February, schoolchildren and preschoolers have inter-semester vacation.  Links: https://archive.fo/wip/dYf7v, https://archive.fo/r0SkT and https://archive.fo/REcKf

According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, fairs, mixed, flying and flea markets will be forbidden. Also, for the economic operators having activities in closed and/or open spaces, (public or private) to organize their activity only between 05:00 and 21:00. According to the Decision 56/4.12.2020, it is proposed to resume the activity of agri-food markets organized in closed spaces. According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces. Also, to avoid the congestion of public transport, it is proposed to all public institutions and all economic operators to organize work schedule (where telework is not possible) into at least two groups to start/finish the activity at a difference of at least two hours. The Ministry of Health published the recommendations for preventing the spread of coronavirus (working from home where it is possible, people should avoid crowded areas and limit to the maximum any direct contact with other people, other than those who are part of the same family). Also, according to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 (extended through Decision 58/10.12.20) of The National Emergency Committee, in all localities in Romania, it is in place a ban for traffic persons outside the home between 23:00 and 5:00 (exception for travel in professional interest, for medical assistance). The Ministry of Interior published the list of quarantined localities.  Link: https://archive.fo/cUlEp,  https://archive.fo/T7Aib, https://web.archive.org/web/20201212161456/https://www.gov.ro/fisiere/pagini_fisiere/Hotarare_CNSU_nr._58_din_10.12.2020.pdf and https://archive.fo/un88p

Link: https://archive.fo/cUlEp,  https://archive.fo/T7Aib, https://web.archive.org/web/20201212161456/https://www.gov.ro/fisiere/pagini_fisiere/Hotarare_CNSU_nr._58_din_10.12.2020.pdf and https://archive.fo/un88p

The Ministry of Health published the recommendations for preventing the spread of coronavirus (working from home where it is possible, people should avoid crowded areas and limit to the maximum any direct contact with other people, other than those who are part of the same family). The Ministry of Interior published the list of quarantined localities. There are screening procedures implemented at the “Henri Coanda” International Airport (three thermal scanners and a joint action plan with the Border Police and the Public Health Directorate to collect questionnaires from travelers arriving in the country and to distribute information about local measures and restrictions). The measures introduced by GEO 30/2020 include:   1.	The criteria for sending employees into technical unemployment and minimum income ensured for freelancers working in industries where activity is reduced or interrupted due to the pandemic.  2.	The conditions for granting free paid days to parents, to supervise their children during the temporary closure of educational establishments.  3.	The online submission of the documentation needed to gain access to social benefits.  4.	The measures for ensuring continuity in the granting of return to work incentives and childcare allowance, as well as for facilitating access to medical leave and medical leave indemnities for quarantined persons.    Link: https://archive.fo/FtT0q

On 22nd of October, the government approved the application of the simplified alternative procedure for granting payment rescheduling for a maximum of 12 months. Beneficiaries of the simplified staggering facility are all taxpayers.  According to Emergency Ordinance 69/14.05.2020, the authorities have adopted fiscal measures to help taxpayers overcome the problems caused by the COVID-19 pandemic (granting bonuses, extension of the deadline for submitting the Single Declaration, tax facilities for incentives and bonuses granted by the employer from the salary fund for the period of emergency to employees whose activity involves risk of infection with SARS-CoV-2, bonuses regarding the annual building tax and the monthly building tax, cancellation of ancillary payment obligations.  Link: https://archive.fo/OJIQT and https://archive.fo/hVM21

Ministry of Health published “Recommendations on responsible social behavior in preventing the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19)” and “Recommended measures to reduce the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic”. On 29th of October, The Government of Romania announced the List of infection diseases for which the isolation of persons is established at their home. The same document establishes the basic health units in which sick people can be treated with diseases provided in the list of infectious diseases. It was released the National Information Platform on vaccination against COVID-19.  Links: https://archive.fo/cUlEp, https://archive.fo/klswT , https://archive.fo/Vi0vG and https://archive.fo/O0MTX#selection-697.0-697.76

An official document regarding contact tracing and testing of contacts of COVID-19 confirmed patient was released by National Center for Surveillance and Control of Transmissible Diseases on 23rd of July 2020. On 28th of October, the Ministry of Health published updated the flow of information used in reporting SARS CoV-2 virus infection data.  According to this document, the Directorates of Public Health (DSP) have the obligation to identify and confirm, following the epidemiological investigation, direct contacts of each person tested positive.   Link: https://archive.fo/thRdi and https://archive.fo/FUhtr

According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 (extended through Decision 58/10.12.2020) of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces, regardless the value of the cumulative incidence rate of cases in the last 14 days (as it previously of this decision was). Second stage of the vaccination campaign started on 15th of January and is aimed at people over 65 age, people with chronic diseases (regardless of age) and key staff working in key areas. The coordinator of the National Committee for the Planning of COVID-19 Vaccination in Romania, announced how the appointments of people over 65 years of age and those with chronic diseases can be made. (Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are used).  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/IzHsa and https://archive.fo/wip/qeZ7F

About 15 schools in 15 regions of Russia are closed due to COVID-19. However, the government announced that universities will be open from 8 February.   Links: https://archive.vn/HqAeV https://archive.vn/zwu1m

Russian authorities are progressively albeit tentatively reinstating restrictions amid a steep rise in daily infections and hospitalizationsthat started in September 2020. While still resisting a tough lockdown , the regions are extending and increasingly reinstating a limited number of restrictions: : self-isolation (81 regions out of 85), remote work (63), mass gatherings (74), entertainment and eating establishments (82), unaccompanied child mobility (40), non-emergency medical care (36); and online learning. https://web.archive.org/web/20210118234814/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Moscow's museums, exhibitions, libraries, and cultural centers re-opened to visitors, Mayor Sergei Sobyanin announced. New regulations also allow for cinemas, theaters, and concert halls to fill up to 50% of seats.  Link: https://archive.vn/uuQ9R

No policy change.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210131221636/http://government.ru/en/news/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210131223407/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210131220539/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Moscow has lifted some measures aimed at slowing the spread of the coronavirus as cases continued to recede over the past week, Mayor Sergei Sobyanin announced Wednesday. The measures include the requirement for 30% of all businesses' employees to work remotely and restaurant curfews.  Link: https://archive.vn/uuQ9R

Moscow and Saint Petersburg have lifted a number of restrictions. Currently, in Saint Petersburg theaters, museums, and other cultural venues may not exceed the 50-percent capacity. Earlier, the limit was 25 percent.   Links: https://archive.vn/H4TXW https://archive.vn/SOe9e https://archive.vn/JZYIB

According to the Decree ? 2393 from 31 December 2020, the government extended the maximum amount of unemployment benefits until the end of 2021 due to COVID-19. The maximum allowance will remain at 12,130 rubles. In the first three months, an unemployed citizen will be paid 75 percent of lost salary, and the second three months – 60 percent of lost salary.   It should be mentioned that in March 2020 the maximum amount of unemployment benefits was increased from 8,000 rubles to 12,130 rubles. Initially, this was a temporary government measure to support unemployed citizens during COVID-19. However, at the end of 2020, the government decided to keep the maximum allowance in 2021 at the same level as before. On October 28th, the government of the Russian Federation reinstated a requirement to wear masks in crowded public areas, including public transportation, taxis, parking lots, and elevators.  This order applies to the entire country. Regions and cities set their own fines for violating rules on social distancing, wearing masks, etc.  In Moscow, individuals not wearing masks and gloves on public transportation or in stores may be fined 5,000 rubles.  Link: https://archive.vn/4ShjR

C:  Sputnik V  On 17 January, the mass free and voluntarily vaccination against COVID-19 was launched. The jab is now available to everyone, not only people in the risk groups.     Since this article also discusses regional variability and producing enough vaccine, for now, keeping as a single group until there is further evidence more groups are able to vaccinate broadly.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210131231130/http://government.ru/en/news/41349/

C:    From 26 January remarks:  Currently, most people are being vaccinated with Sputnik V. Next month we will switch to the large-scale production of EpiVacCorona. It is already being introduced into civilian circulation. The Government has earmarked over 2 billion roubles for its manufacture.  The Healthcare Ministry has received documents for registering one more vaccine. It was developed by the Chumakov Centre. This is already a third vaccine developed by our scientists. It will go into civilian circulation in the next few months. All this will allow us to expand vaccination and make it more accessible, thereby protecting more people against the coronavirus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210131221853/http://government.ru/en/news/41389/

From 18 January 2021, Russia launched a mass vaccination policy for free. Everyone 18+can receive a vaccine on a voluntary basis. It should be mentioned that during December only elderly people, medical workers, and people with chronic diseases had an opportunity to receive vaccines. Now, there are no such restrictions. Since the vaccination on a voluntary basis and the number of people to get vaccinated only increasing.      Links: https://archive.vn/kmTXE https://archive.vn/jkeWX https://archive.vn/qTPC4 https://archive.vn/0s2lb

Classes in primary and secondary schools will be continued from 18 January according to the dynamics that took place in September. High school students will attend classes every other week (half a class in a shift), and elementary school students will go to school every other day.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111194136/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166089/all-epidemiological-measures-remain-in-force.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111202631/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166116/government-adopts-recommendation-of-crisis-response-team-to-keep-current-measures.php
No changes recorded.

The Education Ministry said earlier that elementary and high schools would reopen using the same model for classes that was in place since September 1 which means that elementary school children in grades 1 to 4 will go to school every day in smaller groups while grades 5 to 8 will go to school every other day and online. High school students will either go to school one week and have online classes every other week or stay at home for online schooling to the end of the year. Classes will be 30 minutes long instead of the customary 45 and the school year will be five days longerr because of the coronavirus pandemic.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210118234843/https://rs.n1info.com/english/news/serbian-schools-start-second-semester-teachers-unhappy/

No policy changes. On 19 January, the government stated current epidemiological measures remain in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210124213602/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166458/current-epidemiological-measures-in-force-until-further-notice.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124214514/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/sekcija/en/151926/covid-19.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124213414/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

From 14 January 2021, individuals coming to the Republic of Serbia from all countries across the world, excluding the Republic of Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Republic of Bulgaria, Republic of North Macedonia and Montenegro, shall be allowed to enter the Republic of Serbia solely provided they have a negative PCR test, not older than 48 hours. A, C:      The Prime Minister Ana Brnabic stated that that there will be enough vaccines available for all citizens who want to be vaccinated against coronavirus (agreements exist for 8 million doses for 4 million of inhabitants). The plan for mass immunisation will be adopted by the crisis response team during the week of 18-24 January 2021.  Brnabic expressed the expectation that the first vaccination point will be opened at the Belgrade Fair by the end of the week of 18-24 January, adding that from 11 January, citizens will be able to apply to the system through which they will be able to express their desire to be vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111212830/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166035/preconditions-for-beginning-of-mass-vaccination-provided.php    Two groups coded as insufficient evidence to warrant higher code

A, C. No change recorded in groups.    Pfizer, Sputnik V vaccine.    "On January 16, Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic said that the country expected to receive an additional 250,000 doses of Sputnik V vaccine on Tuesday. According to Vucic, Serbia would vaccinate 80 percent of its seven million population with vaccines developed by different pharmaceutical companies.  "As of today, 28 percent are in favor of receiving Pfizer vaccine, 40 percent have chosen Sputnik V, the others do not care which one [to choose]," Derlek said during a television appearance."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210119002717/https://sputniknews.com/world/202101181081797801-live-updates-global-coronavirus-death-toll-reaches-2-million-people/

Pfizer, Sputnik V, and Sinopharm are currently in use. Negotiations are in progress for the AstraZeneca vaccine.    On 19 January, mass vaccinations began at the Belgrade Fair, Brnabic reiterated that mass vaccination of Serbian citizens is starting today and to that purpose, the first big vaccination site is opened at the Belgrade Fair and at the Torlak Institute. She specified that the first ones to be vaccinated are members of the Ministry of the Interior, the Serbian Army and other security services.    The Secretary of State appealed to the citizens to apply for vaccination in as many numbers as possible, but also to adhere to the protection and distance measures.    Because Serbia is also working on acquiring more vaccine, did not yet code as 5 as the policy as there isn't evidence yet that access is Universal with the limited supply.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210124220302/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166671/very-good-start-of-immunisation-in-serbia.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124220013/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166467/mass-vaccination-at-18-points-starts-in-belgrade.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124220138/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/166398/mass-vaccination-in-serbia-starts-today.php

Sputnik V, Pfizer-BioNTech and Sinovac are used.  All people can registered for vaccination but not coded 5 since since the country does not have currently enough vaccines  (had 1,170,000 doses). Contracts have been signed for more than 6.5 million vaccines, and on February 1 and 2 more contracts will be signed according to the Prime minister, which will bring the total number of purchased vaccines to 11 million.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210201210655/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/167043/serbia-has-vaccinated-438000-people.php

Pfizer/BioNtech, Sputnik V, or Sinopharm are available following registration of interest on government website.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210207182631/https://www.euractiv.com/section/enlargement/news/with-chinas-help-serbia-overtakes-eu-in-vaccine-rollout/

Pfizer/BioNtech, Sputnik V, Sinopharm    It is expected that Sputnik V will begin to be produced in Serbia in the next couple of months.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210213235518/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/167453/all-epidemiological-measures-remain-in-force.php  https://web.archive.org/web/20210214001224/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/167721/first-phase-of-russian-vaccine-production-in-torlak-approved.php

Starting Monday, 08 February, Slovakia will adopt the COVID-19 "Automat" Traffic Light System, which will update pandemic control measures regionally based on predetermined criteria.  Anyone physically present in a district in the black or dark red phase must carry with them outside their homes proof of a negative test less than 7 days old, a complete vaccination (two doses, plus 14 days have passed since the second dose), or proof of recovery from COVID-19 not more than three months ago.      As of 05 February, all of Slovakia is in the black phase.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210206202810/https://korona.gov.sk/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/ciastka_19_2021.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206200912/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206202439/https://sk.usembassy.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/193/Feb-5-Traffic-Light-System.pdf    For schools, no policy changes until 08 February, when some schools will be allowed to re-open.  As of 05 Friday, there was indication that some municipalities may choose not to re-open.    School guidelines in black phase:  - Kindergarten, Primary 1-4 grades - in person  - Primary, Secondary - only ending grades - in person  - Testing required  - University – online    https://web.archive.org/web/20210206203735/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22588626/news-digest-slovakia-will-follow-new-rules-from-monday-children-will-return-to-schools.html?ref=njctse  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206204158/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22590217/news-digest-british-variant-widespread-across-the-country.html

From 08 February, some schools decided to physically re-open, while others decided to stay with distance education.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210213192819/https://bratislavskykraj.sk/v-malackach-sa-skoly-otvarat-nebudu-pokracuju-v-distancnom-vzdelavani/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210213192940/https://bratislavskykraj.sk/prezencne-vyucovanie-sa-obnovilo-na-styroch-zupnych-skolach/
