Update immunization policy is in place from 18 January – currently health care professionals and other workers in health care facilities are eligible + newly also old people in nursing homes. People from critical infrastructure will be moved to the list of replacements, meaning they will receive the vaccination only if there is unused vaccine or someone fails to attend.    In the second phase:  residents of senior's homes and people over 65, patients with serious diagnoses, such as diabetes, oncological diseases, auto-immune diseases, cardiovascular issues and other chronic diseases     In the third phase: people in communities with a high risk of fast coronavirus spread like teachers, people living in marginalised Roma communities, homeless people and asylum seekers    In the fourth phase: members of the general public older than 18     https://web.archive.org/web/20210118213749/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22574807/vaccination-strategy-to-change.html

A,C:    Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna    As of 05 February, it was expected to add AstraZeneca in the following week. In addition, the Health Ministry is considering ordering the Russian-made Sputnik V vaccine.     https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22590217/news-digest-british-variant-widespread-across-the-country.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206212305/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22589821/should-people-be-able-to-choose-their-vaccine-its-better-not-to-say-experts-and-ministry.html?ref=av-center

A,C:    Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca    Currently, vaccination is available for healthcare workers (A), students of medicine and non-medical specializations in contact with Covid-19 patients (A), workers in nursing homes (A) and people older than 75 (C). Teachers (A), together with people working in critical infrastructure (A), will be vaccinated on weekends, starting 13 February.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210213195642/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22594546/vaccination-strategy-changes-again-teachers-will-receive-the-jab-sooner-than-planned.html

No policy change. In Slovenia, distance learning is carried out in all primary, music and secondary schools and in faculties. Kindergartens have been working in a limited capacity.  https://archive.vn/508cI

From 23rd January, in  in nine out of 12 regions of Slovenia, kindergartens and the first three years of primary school are permitted to reopen.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125041347/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/432806/slovenia-covid-19-related-domestic-restrictions-eased-in-nine-regions-from-jan-23-update-24

From 15 February 2021, all of Slovenia will be considered Orange. This means that the following rules apply across the country:  - All kindergartens, primary schools, adult education centres and vocational high schools will open for face to face classes. High School senior students will also attend classes in person.    Link: https://archive.vn/5fDPt

From 23rd January, in  in nine out of 12 regions of Slovenia,  limited nonessential businesses and services can reopen including markets, museums, libraries, hairdressers, and mechanics.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125041347/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/432806/slovenia-covid-19-related-domestic-restrictions-eased-in-nine-regions-from-jan-23-update-24

From 6 February, libraries, museums, galleries and outdoor cultural heritage sites are permitted to open across the country.  The following domestic measures also remain in effect:  - Nonessential businesses and facilities are closed; businesses that are permitted to open must implement strict hygiene and social distancing measures.  - Restaurants, cafes, and bars may only offer carryout services.  - Facemasks are mandatory in all nonrural public spaces.    From 15 February 2021, all of Slovenia will be considered Orange. The following rules apply across the country:  - A wider range of shops and services are open. Some services will only be allowed to open if they provide weekly testing for their staff. Consumers are not required to provide a negative Covid-19 test to access any services that are open.  - Hotels are closed, with a few limited exemptions to allow for business/diplomatic stays or for professional sports teams.  - Restaurants and bars are closed. Takeaway services are open and permitted.  Link: https://archive.vn/5fDPt

A temporary ban on gathering is being imposed throughout the Republic of Slovenia. Temporarily are prohibited all events, gatherings, celebrations, weddings and religious ceremonies.   Link: https://archive.vn/508cI
No policy change. Gathering is permitted only to groups of persons who are close family members or share the same household.  https://archive.vn/508cI

A temporary ban on gathering is being imposed throughout the Republic of Slovenia. Temporarily are prohibited all events, gatherings, celebrations, weddings and religious ceremonies. Gathering is permitted only to groups of persons who are close family members or share the same household.    Public gatherings: Gatherings outside of a household are limited to 10 persons and still require proper precautions such as masks.    Link: https://archive.vn/508cI  https://archive.vn/QeWgS

Public passenger transport is to be carried out to the registered extent in the whole of Slovenia.. All passengers using public transport are obliged to wear masks, disinfect hands and comply with the rules regarding entry and exit from vehicles. All passengers are advised to purchase their tickets in advance.  Link: https://archive.vn/508cI    Internal train/bus service: Limited service (holiday schedules).  Passengers must disinfect their hands upon entry, wear a face mask and keep a safety distance of at least 1.5 meters.  The Infrastructure Ministry has established a hotline at 01 478 85 12 to address questions on public transportation.    Link: https://archive.vn/QeWgS

TO REVIEWERS - suggest revision of previous scores    Restriction of movement between 21:00 and 6:00. Movement of people on the entire territory of the Republic of Slovenia is temporarily prohibited between 22:00 and 6:00 with the following exceptions:  - the elimination of immediate threats to health, life and property;  - travel to and from work and the performance of urgent work duties;  - access to and provision of emergency services;  - delivery of food or medicines;  - the travel of persons who have entered the Republic of Slovenia in order to transit to a neighbouring country or to their residence in the Republic of Slovenia.    Link: https://archive.vn/508cI
No policy change. Movement between municipalities is prohibited with certain exceptions for which adequate proof must be submitted.  https://archive.vn/508cI

Movement between municipalities is prohibited with certain exceptions for which adequate proof must be submitted.  Movement between municipalities is allowed in the following cases:  - travel to and from work and the performance of work duties;  - the performance of business, agricultural and forestry activities;  - the elimination of immediate threats to health, life and property;  -the provision of care and assistance to persons in need of support, care of family members, or ---parental care or contact with one’s children;  -access to pharmacies, health and sanitary services, and health resort treatment;  -access to foreign diplomatic missions and consular posts;  -access to emergency services;  -access to the performance of tasks related to the operation of judicial, administrative and law enforcement authorities;  -access to services for persons with special needs;  -the performance of maintenance work or seasonal chores on private property for members of the -same household;  -the travel of persons who have entered the Republic of Slovenia in order to transit to a neighbouring country or to their residence in the Republic of Slovenia;  -access to shops or services in another municipality that are closer to the person's residence than the same shops and services in the municipality of their residence or if there are no such shops or services in their municipality;  - urgent maintenance of a grave, in which case the person must demonstrate their eligibility with proof of burial plot lease or other appropriate proof.  -Exceptions also apply to immediate family members  (spouses, cohabiting partners, partners living in formal or non-formal civil unions, divorced spouses or partners whose maintenance was recognised by a court decision, their parents, children) and members of the same household when travelling together.    Link: https://archive.vn/508cI

As of Feb. 12, individuals arriving from most EEA countries or Switzerland must produce proof of a negative COVID-19 PCR test result in order to enter the country; alternatively, they can enter self-isolation for 14 days. However, a PCR test may be taken after eight days, and a negative result will end the isolation period.    Individuals arriving from high-risk non-EU countries must register with authorities and self-isolate for at least eight days, after which a COVID-19 test may be taken; those testing positive are required to self-isolate until they have recovered. Cross-border commuters are not required to self-isolate, though they must be in possession of a negative PCR or antigen COVID-19 test result taken within the previous seven days.     In addition, from Feb. 13, international arrivals who can provide evidence that they have been vaccinated against COVID-19 with two doses or have previously recovered from the virus will be permitted to enter without self-isolation or testing.    Individuals arriving from countries designated as low risk may enter without restriction; these countries include Australia, China, Finland, Iceland, New Zealand, Norway, Singapore, South Korea, and Taiwan.    Link: https://archive.vn/4hToZ  https://archive.vn/kjSkg

On February 3, 2021, an eight package (EUR 320 mn) was approved, which extends the furlough till April and the short-time work scheme till June. The wage subsidy under the furlough was increased from 80 to 100 percent under certain conditions. In addition, the government will cover part of the minimum wage increase for affected businesses and will pay one-off allowances to certain vulnerable groups.  Additional extended measures into 2021 to be found here: https://archive.vn/vYODR  Link: https://archive.vn/WkKzU

Measures related to public guarantees  - The public guarantee scheme with impact beyond 2020 (loans with maturity up to 5 years).  - The deferral of loans by up to 12 months with impact beyond 2020. The sixth anti-corona package allows for additional deferral of loans for 9 months in 2021 (the applications can be submitted to the bank until end of February 2021) in order to mitigate as much as possible the negative consequences of the second COVID-19 epidemic on the economy.  - State guarantees of EUR 30m for bank loans for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, and the reduction of bank costs and of EUR 100 million to cover the first loss of the financial engineering measure in the field of tourism and catering. The measure is implemented by the Public Fund of the Republic of Slovenia for Entrepreneurship and the SID bank  Link: https://archive.vn/vYODR
No policy change    Link: https://archive.vn/40rHj

Testing is available for both foreign nationals and Slovenians.  No appointment is required for the rapid antigen tests (RAT), and they are available throughout the country, including Ljubljana airport.  For the PCR test, available at the Ljubljana Clinical Center, an appointment is required, but is usually available within a day.  For foreign nationals, cost for RAT is 25-30 euro; cost for PCR is 93 euro.  Results for both tests will be provided to you electronically within 24 hours.     Link: https://archive.vn/QeWgS
No information found

No policy change. Masks are mandatory:  - in all closed public spaces,  - on public transport,  - in open public spaces or outside if physical distancing of at least two metres cannot be maintained and  - in personal vehicles.  https://archive.vn/508cI

Masks or other forms of protection covering mouth and nose are mandatory: in all closed public spaces, on public transport, in open public spaces or outside and in personal vehicles.    Link: https://archive.vn/40rHj

A, C:  The vaccination campaign continues, with the priority given to those over 85 and the remainder going to health workers.  The Pfizer vaccine is being used.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118212237/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2021-01-13-rise-in-hospital-admissions/

Pfizer/BionTech & Moderna & AstraZeneca vaccines     The vaccination of people older than 80 continues throughout the country today, including in Ljubljana and Ajdovšcina.    Vaccination is free for all citizens, regardless of whether they are insured or not. Funds for the purchase of vaccines and costs for vaccination are provided in the budget of the Republic of Slovenia.    5 Feb -  Slovenia started vaccinating the elderly in care homes first, as care homes recorded frequent outbreaks and suffered the most fatalities. Apart from the elderly, nursing home and hospital staff are also being vaccinated in Slovenia at the moment.    The country has also recently received the first batch of a vaccine developed by AstraZeneca, which is, however, recommended for a younger population.       Link: https://archive.vn/cwvre  https://archive.vn/OFLYU  https://archive.vn/hH21B

Prior coding still valid till 1/24 as a new policy goes into effect from 1/25.    "The temporary regulations give principals a certain flexibility to make decisions about their activities based on the current infection control situation or local needs. There are opportunities for the principal to take action if the school is open or if the school is or has been closed.    The Swedish Public Health Agency has previously recommended that upper secondary schools partially close and switch to distance education from Monday 7 December 2020 until Wednesday 6 January 2021. The Swedish Public Health Agency has now decided that this recommendation will be extended and apply until 24 January 2021."    Note: Since principals have the authority to decide whether to close high-schools, depending on the regional situation, and this is only a recommendation - making it unlikely for upper-secondary schools to close countrywide - a Targeted flag has been selected.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201221201801/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/regler-for-forskolor-och-skolor-som-ar-oppna-stangda-eller-varit-stangda-under-coronapandemin

"The current recommendation for upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor, usually for 16-18-year olds) to switch to remote learning was extended until April 1st.    From Monday January 25th however it will be adapted so that schools may have some parts of teaching in-person, in combination with distance learning."     https://www.thelocal.se/20210122/swedish-public-health-agency-wear-medical-masks-on-public-transport-not-cloth-masks

The Public Health Agency has recommended that, for the period of 25 Jan-1 April, upper secondary schools (gymnasieskolor) conduct their education partially as distance education and partially at school. This does not include exams which cannot be taken at a distance and vulnerable students. The decision is at the discretion of the school principal, who has a certain flexibility to make decisions about their activities based on the current infection control situation or local needs, which is why this is coded with a Targeted flag.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210204142817/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/coronaviruset---fragor-och-svar-utifran-skollagstiftningen

In addition to the measures mentioned in the previous note, on 10 January, a new covid-19 law came into force which enabled the government to restrict numbers in shops and businesses, and close public places such as shopping centres and gyms. It has not yet mandated such closures, but from 10 January, shops, shopping centers, gyms and bathhouses must calculate the number of visitors to allow for 10 sqm per visitor. In addition, the maximum limit of 8 participants will also apply to private events in party centres and club houses.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210112112903/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/januari/butiker-gym-och-kopcentrum-maste-begransa-antalet-besokare/

Temporary shutdown of public buildings  All activities within the state, municipalities and regions that are not necessary should remain closed until 7 February 2021. This applies, for example, to bathhouses, sports halls and museums.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125005255/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

No change: the temporary shutdown of public buildings continues, so that all activities within the state, municipalities and regions that are not necessary should remain closed until 7 February 2021. This applies, for example, to bathhouses, sports halls and museums.    Shops, gyms, indoor sports facilities, and swimming facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person is given ten square meters of space. The companies must display clear signage that clarifies for visitors how many people may visit the premises at the same time.       There are extensive hygiene measures in place for restaurants, cafés and pubs. The serving of alcoholic beverages and alcoholic beverage-like preparations is prohibited between 20.00 and 11.00 until 7 February 2021.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210204143008/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

Public buildings have reopened on 8th February. Most workplaces can open with special measures in place, but a number of workplaces are forced to close in relation to the ban on public gatherings of over 8 people, such as fairground amusements and parades, and markets and fairs.     Restaurants, cafés and pubs can open, but the size of a dining party allowed to sit at one table is limited to four people. If a party is larger than eight people, they must be divided between several tables with at least one metre between them. The serving of alcoholic beverages is prohibited between 20.00 and 11.00.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210212174105/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

Public gatherings and events may have a maximum of 8 participants meaning that no public events are allowed. The only exception in place is for funerals, where a maximum of 20 participants is allowed.   "Public gatherings include: gatherings that constitute demonstrations or which are otherwise held for discussion, expression of opinion or providing information on public or private matters; lectures and speeches held for the purposes of teaching or for public or civic education; gatherings for religious practice; theatrical and cinema performances, concerts and other gatherings for the performance of artistic work, and other gatherings at which freedom of assembly is exercised.  Public events include: competitions and exhibitions in sports and aviation; dance performances; fairground amusements and parades; markets and fairs circus performances. other events not regarded as public gatherings. Schools, public transport, private events and visits to shops are excluded."   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210115160338/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210115160338/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

Until further notice, no more than eight people may be present at a public gathering or public event. The police has the right to cancel or dissolve an event that has more than eight attendees.   If a private gathering is held at an event venue, in a meeting room and at other rented premises, a maximum of eight people are allowed to attend.    Hence coding is 2G per interpretation guidelines when C4=4    https://web.archive.org/web/20210125005255/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

Anyone who organises an event that violates the ban can face a fine or prison sentence of a maximum of six months. Temporary entry ban to Sweden  The Swedish Government has decided to stop non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. This ban will be in effect until March 31. This ban has been introduced to mitigate the effects of the coronavirus outbreak, and to reduce the spread of Covid-19.   The entry ban does not apply to citizens and their families from EU/EEA countries and Switzerland. Moreover, the ban does not apply if you are a permanent resident or hold a residence permit in Sweden or another EU country, or if you have a national visa in Sweden.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210125010813/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

Still current     https://web.archive.org/web/20210125010813/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

No change: http://web.archive.org/web/20210204143911/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions    Note for next coder: From 6 February, a travel ban on all countries will be introduced, as well as a requirement for a negative Covid-19 test certificate for foreign citizens. The test result must not be older than 48 hours. The new rules supplement the previous entry ban. There will be relaxations and exemptions, including for cross-border workers.

The Swedish Government has decided to stop non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. This ban will be in effect until March 31. This ban has been introduced to mitigate the effects of the coronavirus outbreak, and to reduce the spread of Covid-19.   The entry ban does not apply to citizens and their families from EU/EEA countries and Switzerland. Moreover, the ban does not apply if you are a permanent resident or hold a residence permit in Sweden or another EU country, or if you have a national visa in Sweden.  A temporary ban on entry to Sweden for nationals from the UK, Denmark and Norway is in effect.    Exceptions may be made, such as for:  •    Anyone working or living in Sweden can enter from Denmark.  •    Children going to meet parents living in Sweden and their escort.  •    Those travelling in health service vehicles.    In addition to the entry ban, foreign nationals need to present a negative Covid-19 test result no older than 48h in order to travel into Sweden.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210212193443/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

Short-term lay-offs may currently be granted for a maximum of nine consecutive months. The Government will propose that this time limit be temporarily removed until 30 June 2021. In practice, this means that short-term lay-offs granted in 2020 can be extended by up to a further seven months, or until 30 June 2021 at the latest.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125013744/https://www.government.se/press-releases/2020/11/additional-crisis-measures-for-businesses/

The Public Health Agency of Sweden recommends that adults with symptoms of COVID-19 get tested to see if they have an ongoing infection. The same recommendation applies to children of school age and older, i.e., from about 6 years of age. Younger children of preschool age are primarily advised to stay at home if they are ill, without taking a test. It is the regions that decide which people to test, and there may be regional variations from the national recommendations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210125020028/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/

Commercial flights to and from Tajikistan remain very limited. The Tajik civil aviation authority announced the temporary suspension of all flights to and from Tajikistan on 20 March 2020. However, Fly Dubai has subsequently resumed weekly commercial flights between Dushanbe and Dubai. Somon Air occasionally organises flights from Dushanbe to Moscow and Frankfurt and vice-versa. However, these flights occur sporadically. Turkish Airlines and Somon Air have resumed flights from Dushanbe to Istanbul. Uzbekistan Airways have recently resumed flights from Tashkent to Dushanbe occurring on Wednesdays every week.  Link: https://archive.vn/F7qqf

President of Tajikistan announced the complete victory of Tajikistan over COVID-19. No cases of COVID-19 have been reported since December 30, 2020. In the near future, Tajikistan plans to resume air flights with many countries. However, President has not specified the date/month when the borders with other states will be opened. Diplomat argues that Tajikistan’s government has not proven itself to be an accurate source of information on the pandemic. The government perpetually reproduces the narrative that it is strong, able to face any challenge, and the pandemic has been no different. An RFE/RL investigation last summer concluded that Tajikistan’s official coronavirus statistics didn’t match reality and reporting on the reality has become increasingly difficult. Tajik authorities blocked a critical news website, Akhbor, in April 2020. Also, Tajik authorities changed the country’s Criminal Code to punish reporting “disinformation” on the virus. Moreover, on January 26 Tajikistan President announced that the country does not have COVID-19 cases and the country completely defeated the COVID-19. The President urged citizens to follow hygiene rules.   Links: https://archive.vn/GuRLt https://archive.vn/L94MD https://archive.vn/An4AE
No change recorded.
No changes found

No testing policy has been reported. The previous publications of Diplomat suggested that Tajikistan has a lack of capacity to actually test for the virus in hospitals and the government pressures on staff to avoid diagnosing it. Thus the prevailing belief among analysts that Tajikistan’s official numbers are, at best, vast undercounts and at worst absolute fabrications.  Link: https://archive.vn/GuRLt
No change recorded.
No contact tracing policy has been reported. The country is celebrating the victory over the COVID-19. Link: https://archive.vn/L94MD https://archive.vn/An4AE

The government continues to restrict internal movement. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    "Traffic police check points have been established around major population centres, including Ashgabat, and road users may be subject to temperature screening."    "Domestic flights remain operational, but with a reduced service. Passengers are subject to temperature checks."    "[N]ewspapers report that a COVID-19 test result is required for boarding domestic flights."    "Rail services are suspended."    "Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes. There are some reports of restrictions on interstate travel."    "Domestic flights are operating on a significantly reduced schedule. Security forces have erected checkpoints on roads entering Ashgabat. Checkpoints have also been reported on highways in Balkan, Mary, Lebap, and Dashoguz provinces, where health screenings have been carried out. Special permits are required for travel within or between provinces."    https://archive.fo/cxSs5    https://archive.vn/bUERh#selection-1611.0-1611.348    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20210128074335/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus

Domestic flights are operating on a significantly reduced schedule. Security forces have erected checkpoints on roads entering Ashgabat. Checkpoints have also been reported on highways in Balkan, Mary, Lebap, and Dashoguz provinces, where health screenings have been carried out. Special permits are required for travel within or between provinces.    See security firm Garda website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210201170921/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/437586/turkmenistan-authorities-extend-coronavirus-disease-related-international-and-domestic-travel-restrictions-until-at-least-feb-28-update-9

The government continues to close its border. It should also be noted that the Turkmenistan government still insists "no cases of coronavirus infection have been registered in the country to date."    "All international commercial flights to and from Turkmenistan have been cancelled and land borders are closed to passenger traffic. Some press reporting indicates that international flight restrictions are expected to continue through January 1, 2020."    "Commercial flights to and from Turkmenistan are suspended. Occasional, tightly controlled, charter flights are the only means of entering or leaving the country by air."    "As part of ongoing efforts to limit the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19), authorities in Turkmenistan have extended their suspensions of international flights until at least Jan. 31. Domestic rail and bus services also remain suspended until at least Jan. 31. All land borders with Afghanistan, Iran, Kazakhstan, and Uzbekistan remain closed until further notice. Only Turkmen nationals, permanent residents, diplomats, and workers in critical industries and key infrastructure are permitted to enter the country. All arrivals must undergo a 14-day quarantine in a state-run facility. While freight traffic is generally allowed to transit the border, Turkmen authorities have previously restricted cross-border freight traffic without warning or explanation. All persons departing the country must be in possession of a negative COVID-19 test certificate, signed within the previous 24 hours."    https://archive.fo/cxSs5    https://archive.vn/bUERh#selection-1611.0-1611.348    http://web-old.archive.org/web/20210128074335/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus

Link: https://archive.vn/CQuNg

Starting with 30th of December, all travelers who arrive in Turkey through air, land or sea will be asked to present a negative PCR test result document issued 72 hours prior to arrival. Those who fail to do so at the border gate or seaport will be quarantined in the address to where they are going. Travelers who arrived in Turkey from United Kingdom, Denmark or South Africa in the past 10 days will be asked to present a negative test result done within the past 72 hours, and will be required to quarantine in the address to where they are going.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/QZDze

Starting with 30th of December, all travelers who arrive in Turkey through air, land or sea will be asked to present a negative PCR test result document issued 72 hours prior to arrival. Those who fail to do so at the border gate or seaport will be quarantined in the address to where they are going. Travelers who arrived in Turkey from United Kingdom, Denmark or South Africa in the past 10 days will be asked to present a negative test result done within the past 72 hours, and will be required to quarantine in the address to where they are going.  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/QZDze

Passengers failing to submit a digital or paper copy of a negative PCR test result are not permitted to board the flights. Those who are in transit, are not required to submit a PCR test in Turkey. Passengers departing from the United Kingdom will not be allowed to enter Turkey. All passengers arriving in Turkey through third countries, who visited The United Kingdom within the last 10 days, will be quarantined for 14 days at places selected by the Turkish officials following their arrival. Passengers arriving from Denmark and South Africa should declare their residency address and stay in isolation for 7 days.   Link: https://archive.fo/2qeZb

At midnight on January 25, the intensified quarantine restrictions, which lasted from January 8, ceased to apply in Ukraine. From now and till February 28 inclusive, the country returned to the anti-epidemic rules in force in December 2020. Returning to adaptive quarantine may be considered based on the epidemiological situation.  What is prohibited:  -	Visiting educational institutions by groups of more than 20 people, except for preschool, general secondary, out-of-school and specialized art education institutions.  -	Visiting educational institutions when more than 50% of students and staff of the educational institution are in self-isolation.    /web/20210125185434/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-ukraina-povernulasja-do-karantinnih-obmezhen-jaki-dijali-v-grudni

At midnight on January 25, the intensified quarantine restrictions, which lasted from January 8, ceased to apply in Ukraine. From now and till February 28 inclusive, the country returned to the anti-epidemic rules in force in December 2020. Returning to adaptive quarantine may be considered based on the epidemiological situation.  What is prohibited:  -	The work of business entities in which employees are not provided with masks, no marking on the distance between customers of 1.5 m, and visitors do not have properly worn personal protective equipment.  -	The work of catering establishments from 23:00 to 7:00 (except for delivery and takeaway orders). Settlement operations are terminated after 22:00.  -	Activities of accommodation establishments (except for hotels, rehabilitation centers for people with disabilities, sanatoriums).  -	The work of gyms and fitness centers, if they have more than one person per 20 square meters.   -	Carrying out of discos, work of night clubs and public catering establishments with the organization of leisure.    /web/20210125185434/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-ukraina-povernulasja-do-karantinnih-obmezhen-jaki-dijali-v-grudni

At midnight on January 25, the intensified quarantine restrictions, which lasted from January 8, ceased to apply in Ukraine. From now and till February 28 inclusive, the country returned to the anti-epidemic rules in force in December 2020. Returning to adaptive quarantine may be considered based on the epidemiological situation.  What is prohibited:  Carrying out mass events (performances, holidays, concerts) in educational institutions with the participation of children from more than one group / class and in the presence of visitors.  - Carrying out mass cultural (including concerts), sports, social, advertising and other events in which more than 20 people take part and the distance of 1.5 m between the participants is not observed (exception - official and professional sports events without spectators, notary exams and events necessary to ensure the work of the authorities).  - Carrying out in entertaining establishments and public catering establishments of celebratory actions, banquets, master classes, public events.  - Operation of cinemas and cultural institutions with more than 50% of seats in one hall.  - Reception of visitors in museums, exhibitions, galleries, there is more than one person per 10 square meters.  - Religious events: indoors - subject to the presence of more than one person per 5 square meters. m; in the open air - provided that the distance of 1.5 m between those present is not observed.    /web/20210125185434/https://moz.gov.ua/article/news/maksim-stepanov-ukraina-povernulasja-do-karantinnih-obmezhen-jaki-dijali-v-grudni

On 02 February, the Ministry of Finance presented a detailed analysis of the use of the COVID Response Fund in 2020 by the main budget institutions. In 2020, the amount of funds allocated from the COVID-19 Response Fund made up UAH 78.4 billion out of UAH 80.9 billion. In particular, from the general fund there was used UAH 63.7 billion out of the allocated UAH 72 billion, the special fund - UAH 2.8 billion out of the allocated UAH 6.4 billion.  The Ministry of Economic Development, Trade and Agriculture used UAH 8.8 billion out of UAH 10.7 billion, or 82.1%.  The funds were used to pay unemployment benefits, for one-time compensation to business entities for the payment of a single contribution as the obligatory state social insurance, for the payment of one-time pecuniary aid to business entities.    The Ministry of Social Policy used UAH 4 billion out of UAH 6.8 billion or 59.8% under the general fund and UAH 2.8 billion out of UAH 5.0 billion or 55.5% under the special fund.  The funds are used to provide insurance benefits for temporary incapacity, to make payments to family members of physicians who died due to COVID-19, to provide assistance to children of self-employed persons, to provide one-time financial assistance to insured persons in case of loss of income if their area of activity was completely prohibited during the quarantine restrictions.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210207004150/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/minfin-predstavlyaye-detalnij-analiz-vikoristannya-koshtiv-fondu-borotbi-z-covid-u-2020-roci-golovnimi-rozporyadnikami

On 26 January, the Prime Minister reminded that the National Vaccination Plan envisages 5 stages, in particular, vaccination of medical workers, the military, people in nursing homes, social workers, teachers, etc. The overall goal of the plan, according to Denys Shmyhal, is to cover at least 50% of the population by the end of 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210207004635/https://www.kmu.gov.ua/en/news/premyer-ministr-ukrayina-bude-zabezpechena-neobhidnoyu-kilkistyu-efektivnih-vakcin

Moreover, the government allows continuing online learning for those students who belong to risk groups and have chronic diseases. Uzbekistan extends the ban on flights from Great Britain, Italy, Germany, Denmark, Austria, Australia, the Netherlands, and South Africa until February 1. It should be noted that the government of Uzbekistan suspended flights with the abovementioned countries on 21 December 2020. Link: https://archive.vn/2bXRj https://archive.vn/RsCF1

The ban on flights from Great Britain, Italy, Germany, Denmark, Austria, Australia, the Netherlands, and South Africa is effective until February 1. It should be noted that the government of Uzbekistan suspended flights with the abovementioned countries on 21 December 2020. However, Uzbekistan has recently resumed the flights to Dushanbe, Delhi, and Kazan. On 21 January, the law "On employment of the population" came into force. Accordingly, citizens who lost their jobs in the past 12 months are paid unemployment benefits in the amount of 50 percent of the average monthly wage.   Links: https://archive.vn/AOl4u https://archive.vn/0rGtQ

Support measures. The government reacted quickly and in proportion to the shock experienced by the economy. An Anti-Crisis Fund of UZS 10 trn sum (EUR 950 m or 1.5% of GDP) was created to cover immediate social needs and to support businesses and employment. Since February, a total of about 2.5% of GDP has been spent, accounting for a cumulative increase in social payments of 17% and of minimum wages by 10% (OECD, 2020[19]).    OECD Web Archived Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210206004922/http://www.oecd.org/coronavirus/policy-responses/covid-19-crisis-response-in-central-asia-5305f172/
No changes found

Currently, there is no debt relief policy for a private household. However, the government intends to extend some exemptions and benefits for about 20 thousand businesses in the field of transport, tourism, and catering until the end of 2021.   Link: https://archive.vn/iURBY https://archive.vn/DWk6z https://archive.vn/CTF5S

During the summer, additional support measures were developed, mainly extending measures developed under the initial package and expanding unconditional income support measures for households. According to official data to July, UZS 2.3 trn of tax incentives were provided to economic sectors, and by the end of August, USD 6.1 bn had been spent, mostly to support businesses and household incomes through the Anti-Crisis Fund. The Government of Uzbekistan has established an official Telegram channel for information on COVID-19 related measures. The channel can be found at https://t.me/koronavirusinfouz. Also, the government has launched the hotline - 1003 - for medical questions related to COVID-19, with the information provided in Russian and Uzbek only.   Link: https://archive.vn/5bc9e

According to data collected by the Ministry of Public Education, from October to December, a total of 270 information sessions were conducted based on the UNFPA-developed teachers’ manual on healthy lifestyle, sexual and reproductive health, and COVID-19 prevention in Samarkand region, Tashkent Region and Karakalpakstan. The sessions reached a total of  8365 persons.  • UNICEF, the MoH and the National Agency for Electronic Mass Media (NAEMM) produced and broadcast a talk-show on mental health during COVID-19. The programme focused on pre-school children, adolescents and parents.  • UNICEF, the MoH and NAEMM produced and broadcast a TV programme on pre-school reopening during COVID-19. The programme highlighted the importance ensuring a safe school environment, provided information on measures taken to reduce infection and spread of COVID-19 at school facilities, and highlighted the importance of hygiene and physical distancing.      Web archived link:  http://archive.today/2021.02.09-150100/https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/COVID19%2520SitRep%2520Uzbekistan%252028-01-2021_Final.pdf
Individuals who are showing COVID-19 symptoms will undergo testing at government facilities.  Link: https://archive.vn/hMl5w

Efforts to improve testing capacity, isolation measures, treatment and contact tracing were being scaled up as part of a solid, whole-of-government approach. The country had set up designated COVID-19 triage and treatment centres, and organized hospital structures and administrative systems for patient care.    Web archived link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210209165839/https://www.euro.who.int/en/countries/uzbekistan/news/news/2020/9/uzbekistans-covid-19-response-focuses-on-core-public-health-measures-and-community-resilience

Those who have been in contact with a person who tests positive for COVID-19 will no longer be automatically quarantined but required to self-isolate for 14-days and subject to medical monitoring. For example, on 22 January, a student from the Tashkent state pedagogical university was tested positive for COVID-19, and contact people were recommended to self-isolate for 14 days.
